habitat: This species is regarded as a forest-dweller (Weksler 1996, Percequillo 1998), inhabiting gallery forests and a luxuriant semi-deciduous forest. This species is reported from habitats from 700 to 900 m (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). Recent published data suggest that it also occurs in Cerrado habitats, such as cerradão (a dry woodland savanna), cerrado sensu stricto, and campo úmido (both open habitats), although two specimens were captured in the ecotone with gallery forest (Bonvicino et al. 1998).
threats: The major threats to this species are habitat destruction and fragmentation for conversion to agriculture, livestock and logging (Percequillo and Weksler 2008).
population: This rodent is known from only four localities and there is no information about its population or abundance. Of the four localities where it has been recorded, two have been completed destroyed due to agricultural expansion.

habitat: Esta espécie ocorre no Cerrado e áreas de transição entre Cerrado e Caatinga, Pantanal e Floresta Amazônica (Avila-Pires 1995, Torres-Carvajal 2011). Parece favorecer manchas rochosas (R. Langstroth com. pess. 2016). Única espécie de seu gênero. Apresenta cauda curta e deprimida, não autotômica e escamas espinhosas no dorso e lateralmente. Processos transversos das vértebras caudais aumentando em comprimento da primeira para a quarta vértebra caudal (Torres-Carvajal et al. 2011). Atinge até 105 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Avila-Pires 1995). Espécie ativa durante a noite. Durante o dia são observados na entrada de tocas de 2 a 4 cm de diâmetro, em buracos de 30 a 40 cm de profundidade (Torres-Carvajal et al. 2011). Quando perturbados, inflam os corpos e pressionam contra as paredes da toca (Avila-Pires 1995). Sua dieta é composta de cupins, besouros, aranhas, escorpiões, gafanhotos, centopeias e formigas (Avila-Pires 1995). Há registro de parasitismo por Cruzia rudolphii (Avila et al. 2009), Physaloptera sp. (Avila et al. 2010), Africana dardanelosi (Ávila and Silva 2013), Spinicauda spinicauda (Avila and Silva 2011), entre outros.
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa, na área de distribuição da espécie, causada pela conversão de área naturais em agricultura em larga escala, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. É difícil de detectar, com apenas alguns espécimes registrados na Bolívia  (R. Langstroth com. pess. 2016). Embora seja provavelmente mais abundante do que sugere a escassez de registros, acredita-se que ocorra naturalmente em baixa abundância (R. Langstroth com. pess. 2016).

habitat: São lagartos pequenos, diurnos e noturnos, sendo os maiores do gênero (Moretti 2009). Apresentam membros curtos e cauda menor que o corpo, forrageiam em meio ao folhiço. Utilizam como microhábitat cupinzeiros, troncos caídos, fendas de rochas e detritos do solo (Brandão and Motta 2005, Gonçalves 2012). Como método de defesa, expõe sua cauda sobre o corpo aos predadores, retirando a atenção de áreas vitais para sua sobrevivência, assemelhando-se a um escorpião (Brandão and Motta 2005). Seu padrão de coloração, junto ao seu comportamento e utilização do mesmo microhábitat servem de evidências para seu comportamento mímico a espécies de escorpiões ocorrentes na mesma área (Brandão and Motta 2005). Seus possíveis predadores incluem as espécies de pássaros Penelope superciliaris, Crotophaga ani, Guira guira, Pitangus sulphuratus, Myiarchus spp., Tyrannus melancholicus e Cariama cristata e lagartos maiores como Mabuya nigropunctata, Ameiva ameiva, Cnemidophorus ocellifer e Tupinambis spp (Brandão and Motta 2005). Espécie caracterizada pela ausência de lamelas adesivas nos dígitos, pele granular, escamas pequenas e olhos grandes com pupila redonda. O estojo é composto de cinco escamas em uma conformação assimétrica. Escamas ventrais e dorsais lisas, sendo as ventrais maiores que as dorsais. Poros pré-anais e femorais ausentes. Rostral grande, dorsalmente deprimida; cauda curta (Moretti 2009). Gamble et al (2008), em filogenia com dados moleculares, propôs que Pseudogonatodes é grupo irmão de Coledactylus e propõe que C. brachystoma é um grupo monofilético e irmão de C. meridionalis. Possui comprimento rostro-cloacal entre 14,96-29,06mm e comprimento da cauda de 13,49-27,43mm (Moretti 2009).
threats: A forte pressão antrópica e a agricultura em larga escala causam intensa perda de hábitat em todo o Cerrado, o que pode reduzir o tamanho e/ou causar isolamento de suas subpopulações. Contudo, dada a ampla distribuição das espécies, é improvável que elas possam possam afetar a espécie ao ponto de colocá-la em riso de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. É de fácil visualização  e localmente abundante.

habitat: It was originally found on vegetation or on forest leaf-litter near streams. The type specimen was found in a temporary pond, which has subsequently disappeared. It breeds in temporary ponds.
threats: The type locality of the species has been destroyed by agriculture and human settlement.
population: Surveys to locate this species in recent years have not found any individuals.

habitat:
Males call from natural and artificial grassland areas, near rivulets or temporary ponds. Syntopic Leptodactylus species include L. furnarius, L. fuscus, L. labyrinthicus, and L. ocellatus. Males call under dense vegetation, from within underground chambers or exposed (Giaretta and Costa, 2007).

The reproductive season coincides with the rainy season (September-February). It is thought to reproduce like other members of the Leptodactylus fuscus group i.e. eggs laid in excavated ground chambers close to waterbodies. Clutch size is estimated to be ca 200 eggs (A.A. Giaretta, pers. comm.).
threats: No major threats are currently known for this species (A.A. Giaretta, pers. comm.).
population: This is considered to be a common species (A.A. Giaretta, pers. comm.).

habitat: Individuals of this species were found in open areas (cerrado, campo cerrado, veredas, and campo sujo). No reproductive activity was observed nor tadpoles found. However, in December toadlets were found close to wet areas, but no adults. Leptodactylus troglodytes, Pleurodema diplolistris, and Physalaemus centralis are found in the same habitats as R. veredas (Brandão et al., 2007). Individuals were observed in open areas during the rainy season, but were nowhere to be seen during the dry season. It is possible that they may burrow underground. The presence of some individuals with soil on their heads and developed calluses suggest that they may bury underground. R. veredas uses large temporary pools in the rainy season in the border area of the three states (R. Brandão, pers. comm. 2008).
threats: The main threat in the region is the rapid conversion of land to monoculture of grain crops or trees (Pinus and Eucalyptus). The region is especially fragile due to its sandy soil, easily arable land and the lack of physical barriers for the mechanized treatment of soil, allowing for a rapid land use change. There are, however, populations of this species that are found within conservation areas (Parque Nacional Grande Sertão Veredas, Refúgio de Vida Silvestre Veredas do Oeste Baiano, Parque Estadual da Serra das Araras and another four private natural heritage reserves in the area of the three state borders, such as  São Francisco da Trijunção, Sertão do Formoso, Guará and Leite Verde) (R. Brandão, pers. comm. 2008).
population: It is an infrequently encountered species, seen mostly at the beginning of the rainy season (October/November) (Brandão et al., 2007). It is less common than other congeneric sympatric species: R. granulosa; R. schneideri; R. cerradensis; however, it cannot be considered as rare (R. Brandão, pers. comm. 2008).

habitat: Scinax cabralensis can be found in marshes, lakes, seasonal and permanent streams and rivers, and shrubby savanna habitats. Reproduction coincides with the rainy season (L.O. Drummond, pers. comm.). Calling males are found in high densities, during the beginning of the rainy season. They are nocturnal callers, calling from perches on the emergent shrubby vegetation and on the ground or rocks, at the margins of temporary and permanent streams, ponds, and marshes. Dendropsophus minutus, Elachistocleis ovalis, Leptodactylus labyrinthicus, Physalaemus cuvieri, Pseudopaludicola cf. mystacalis, Pseudopaludicola saltica, Scinax squalirostris and Scinax sp. were found in activity in the same site of S. cabralensis (Drummond et al., 2007).
threats: Fires are frequent at Serra do Cabral and they always sweep a great part of the area. There are also extensive pine plantations as well as small cattle ranching in the area. Although the species is found within a reserve, this protected area does not currently have an adequate infrastructure. The amphibian species of the area are also used as fishing bait by local inhabitants. In addition, the species' area of occurrence is small (L.O. Drummond, pers. comm.).
population: The species is considered to be locally abundant (L.O. Drummond, pers. comm.).

habitat:
The vegetation at the type locality (Panga) includes several Cerrado physiognomies, including “Veredas” (a vegetation dominated by grass-like plants, with dispersed bushes and Mauritia flexuosa palms) and a riverine forest running along the Panga River (2 m wide). Human altered areas are covered by the exotic grass Brachiaria sp.. The local weather presents a hot and wet summer (Sep.–Mar.), and a cold and dry winter (Apr.–Aug), when frosts may occur. Males were heard calling on the ground or perched (up to 60 cm height) amidst dense tufts of natural grass-like herbs in Veredas or on Brachiaria sp. Up to 200 m from permanently wet soil. Rarely, when fires cleared open areas from
grasses, males were heard also from within forests or forest borders. Calling activity was observed between October and March, being most intense in the afternoon and first hours of the night (Giaretta et al., 2007).
threats: Natural wildfires may comprise a potential threat to this species.
population: No population status information is currently available for this species.

habitat: Rhinella cerradensis is known to occur in open Cerrado physiognomies (Cerrado and Campo Sujo). Adults were observed in March (end of the rainy season), and August to October of 2002 (from dry season to just before the beginning of the rainy season). The species is sympatric with R. schneideri and R. veredas in western Bahia and Piauí states, and with R. schneideri and R. rubescens in the states of Distrito Federal (R. schneideri and R. rubescens were found breeding in the same permanent pond as R. cerradensis in Brasília) and Goiás. R. cerradensis is predated upon by Conepatus striatus (Mammalia: Mustelidae). The elongate and well developed inner metatarsal tubercle suggests that R. cerradensis might bury itself during the dry Cerrado season as do other Neotropical species (e.g., Eupemphix nattereri, Pleurodema diplolistris, and Odontophrynus cultripes). (Maciel et al., 2007).
threats:
The Cerrado system in which the species exists is severely threatened by increasing deforestation, charcoal
production, and large hydroelectric dams (Maciel et al., 2007).
population: Considered to be a rare species in the areas where it has been recorded (N. Maciel, pers. comm.).

habitat: This is a nocturnal species of open wetlands, and appears to preferentially occur in well-vegetated sites close to forest fragments (Nunes et al. 2010). It has been recorded from seasonal marshes during the October to March wet season, but in common with congeners is presumed to be active year-round around both temporary and permanent standing water (I. Nunes pers. comm. December 2010). The breeding mode is unknown, but frogs are presumed to breed in pond habitats.
threats: Known populations of this species are found among natural Cerrado vegetation within a landscape undergoing agro-industrial expansion for maize, soya and sorghum (Nunes et al. 2010). Animals may be reliant on the presence of nearby forest, which exists only in isolated fragments within the frog's range; however as this species' is able to tolerate at least some degree of habitat degradation, it is unclear to what extent agricultural development represents a threat (I. Nunes pers. comm. December 2010).
population: This is a common species at known sites (I. Nunes pers. comm. December 2010), but no information is available on population trends. In common with related species, this frog is likely to have strong dispersal abilities and so may be widespread throughout its range (I. Nunes pers. comm. December 2010).

habitat: It occurs on the ground in the Cerrado near waterbodies, where it also breeds. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, crops and livestock, dam construction and fires are major threats to the species' habitat.
population: It is a locally abundant species.

habitat: It occurs in open areas, and is associated with permanent streams and ponds, where the females lay their eggs. It appears to adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance, even occurring in urban areas.
threats: Agriculture, fire and dam construction are major threats to the species' habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It inhabits dense gallery forest in the Cerrado savannah. Animals have been found close to streams and waterfalls, and this species breeds in small pools in slow-flowing streams. It might also occur in pastureland, although this requires verification.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: This is a seasonally abundant species.

habitat: It occurs at the margins of lakes and pools of stagnant water in tropical rainforest and in Bolivia it is found in seasonally flooded forest. Its breeding habits are unknown, but the larvae are likely to develop in water.
threats: Habitat loss due to agricultural activities is a threat to this species.
population: It is common at one site in Bolivia. Its status elsewhere is unknown.

habitat: It is found in the leaf-litter of gallery forests, near streams or small ponds. It lays its eggs on land, and the larvae are then carried by the parents to streams where they develop further.
threats: The major threats to this species’ habitat are agriculture (both cultivation of crops and rearing of livestock), as well as logging, mining, fire, agricultural pollution and dam construction.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat: Individuals were found amidst leaf-litter in gallery forests in the Cerrado, which is also its breeding habitat. The eggs are laid on land and then the larvae are deposited in streams where they develop further. It probably does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as fire is threats to the species' habitat.
population: The population status of this species is not known.

habitat: A diurnal species found in rock crevices at creek margins in rupestrian fields, within the vegetation on a forest waterfall and amidst leaf-litter. Eggs are laid on the litter and tadpoles are then carried by their parents to streams where they develop further. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging, mining, fires and dam construction are major threats to the species’ habitat. It is in the international pet trade, but not at a level to constitute a threat to the species.
population: It is a locally common species.

habitat: It occurs among dead tree branches on the leaf-litter of tropical moist and dry forest. Eggs are laid on the leaf-litter; tadpoles are carried on the adult's back to temporary pools. Animals can occur in primary and secondary forest, at forest edges and in lightly degraded habitats.
threats: No major threats, a widespread species with large areas of suitable habitat remaining. There is some localized habitat loss to different human activities such as agriculture (crops, livestock etc.). A. picta is not often encountered in the pet trade.
population: It is a very common species.

habitat: It is a species of open, rocky high-altitude grassland that is often found on stones at the edge of brooks and streams. It breeds in permanent streams.
threats: The main threats are habitat degradation due to human settlement, tourism and fire.
population: It is a very common species.

habitat: It occurs in low vegetation next to permanent bodies of water, where it also breeds. It most likely lays its eggs in the water. It adapts well to human disturbance and is often found in pastures.
threats: Logging, fires and dam construction are major threats to the species' habitat.
population: It is a locally abundant species.

habitat: It occurs on low vegetation in and surrounding temporary and permanent ponds (in which it presumably breeds), in open areas.
threats: The major threats to this species’ habitat are agricultural development (for both crops and livestock), as well as logging and dam construction.
population: The population status of this species is not known.

habitat: It occurs in gallery forests along streams, in which it breeds.
threats: Logging, mining and fires are major threats to its habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: This species occurs on vegetation near streams in primary and secondary forest, and also in forest edge and forest clearings. It breeds in permanent streams. It has also been found in plantations.
threats: There are no threats to this very common species.
population: This is a very common species.

habitat: It occurs in small streams in gallery forests, where they also breed. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging and the construction of dams are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs on low vegetation in and surrounding temporary and permanent ponds (in which it presumably breeds), in open areas.
threats: The major threats to its habitat are agricultural development (for both crops and livestock), as well as logging and the construction of dams.
population: The population status of this species is not known.

habitat: It occurs on vegetation near permanent and temporary streams (where it breeds) in forest and open areas.
threats: The major threat to this species is habitat degradation due to smallholder livestock grazing, fire, and infrastructure development for human settlement.
population: It is common.

habitat: It occurs on vegetation near permanent and temporary waterbodies in open areas, where it also breeds. It adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Logging and dam construction are threats to the species' habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs on low vegetation in and surrounding temporary and permanent ponds, in open areas. It presumably breeds in ponds. It is not known whether or not it adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging and dam construction are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: It is a locally common species.

habitat: It occurs on vegetation near streams in gallery forest, and presumably breeds in streams. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Mining, fires, and infrastructure development for human settlement are major threats to the species' habitat. The disturbance of the habitat by tourists is also a problem.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs in rocky habitats in savannah, on stones or trees near small waterfalls of permanent streams. There is no information regarding its breeding habits, but it is likely to breed by larval development in steams.
threats: Potential threats to this species include habitat degradation due to agricultural development and infrastructure development for human settlement and tourism, and also fires.
population: There is no information regarding its population status.

habitat: It occurs on the upper parts of low vegetation, and inhabits springs, streams, and marshes, where it also breeds. It also adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Logging and dam construction are major threats to the species' habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs in the Pantanal, Cerrado, and flooded savannahs. It breeds on low vegetation near waterbodies such as rivers or in marshy grounds. It is not well adapted to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by agriculture is a major threat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs in rock crevices in permanent or temporary streams. Spawning occurs in both these sites. Tadpoles were found attached to stones on the bottom of pools within deep sections of permanent streams with small waterfalls and quartzitic rocks. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging and dam construction are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: It is an uncommon species.

habitat: It is found on the top of blades of grass in savannahs, and breeds in temporary and permanent ponds.
threats: The main threats to this species are thought to be fire and agricultural pollution.
population: This is a very common species where it is known to occur.

habitat: It inhabits the Cerrado and occurs on the emergent or marginal herbaceous vegetation near ponds, pools, or lagoons in open areas. It breeds in permanent and temporary ponds, near grassland vegetation. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging, fires, and the construction of dams are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: It is very common in Brazil, but is uncommon in Bolivia and Paraguay.

habitat: It occurs on stones and rocks near permanent and temporary streams with running water in the Cerrado. The egg clutches are attached to the substrate and are well sheltered in rock crevices or under stones. Tadpoles are found only in permanent streams where males also call. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as fire, and the disturbance of the habitat by tourists is a major threat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: This species inhabits gallery forests and occurs on low vegetation in the margins of streams. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance. The larvae are found in small ponds at the edges of the streams.
threats: The major threats to its habitat are agricultural development (for both crops and livestock), as well as logging, fires and the construction of dams.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat: The specimens were collected in savannah. This species is believed to be a stream breeder.
threats: Mining and infrastructure development are major threats to the habitat in the region of the type locality, although there is no information known regarding specific threats to this species.
population: It has not been collected again since it was first described, and its current population status is not known.

habitat: It is an aquatic species of open flooded savannah areas, and floating meadows of large rivers. It breeds in the associated waterways.
threats: No threats are known.
population: It is common where it occurs.

habitat: This species occurs in streams in gallery forests and open areas. The eggs are deposited on leaves above the water, and fall into the permanent stream below when hatched. It has not been recorded from anthropogenic habitats.
threats: Habitat loss due to infrastructure development for human settlement, and disturbance of the habitat from touristic activities and fire are threats to the species.
population: It is a very common species.

habitat: It is an aquatic species, and is found in permanent ponds, lakes and swamps, where it also breeds. Its ability to adapt to modified habitats is not known.
threats: Expanding agriculture is impacting its populations, overgrazing by domestic livestock, infrastructure development (for expanding human settlements, and dams), and water pollution from agriculture.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It inhabits the Cerrado savannah, and occurs on the ground or on low vegetation near ponds or small lakes, where it also breeds.
threats: The major threats to this species' habitat are agricultural development (for both crops and livestock) and fires.
population: The population status of this very poorly known species is not known.

habitat: It lives on the ground near streams inside forest, and breeds in the streams.
threats: There has been a huge urban expansion within this species' known range, with much forest being lost, and streams becoming polluted.
population: Two of the three known populations disappeared in the mid 1980s, the surviving population is from Serra do Caraça, with records dating from 2001-2002.

habitat: It lives in the leaf-litter of gallery forests and open areas in the Cerrado. It breeds in the leaf-litter and breeds by direct development. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agriculture, both crops and livestock, as well as logging, agricultural pollution, fires and dam construction are major threats to the species’ habitat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs on vegetation in gallery forests in the Cerrado savannah, and breeds by direct development, although there is no information known about the egg deposition site. It probably does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Agricultural development, involving both crops and livestock, as well as logging and fires, are major threats to this species’ habitat. Disturbance of the habitat by tourists is also a problem.
population: It is a reasonably common species.

habitat: It is an inhabitant of the Pantanal wetlands, and it is presumed to breed by direct development, like other species of the genus.
threats: It is likely to be threatened by habitat changes as a result of livestock farming.
population: The population status of this species is not known.

habitat: It occurs at permanent stream margins in riparian forests in primary and secondary gallery forests. Larvae were found in the same streams.
threats: Habitat degradation due to tourism and fire are the major threats to this species.
population: It is not a very common species.

habitat: It occurs in Cerrado savannah on the ground near permanent waterbodies, where it also breeds. It vocalizes in open areas. It adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance (even occurring in urban areas).
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: This inhabitant of the Cerrado savannah lays its eggs in subterranean foam nests (sometimes under stones), and the larvae are then carried to water such as puddles, swamps or temporary ponds.
threats: Logging and fires are threats to this species. Disturbance of its habitat by tourists is also a major threat.
population: It is an uncommon species.

habitat: A fossorial species that can be found in open areas and forest edges. It reproduces explosively in temporary pools (including artificial pools).
threats: Severe habitat loss due to infrastructure development and agricultural activities (cattle ranching) can impact this species, and its habitat is fragmented.
population: It is an abundant and stable species. It occurs in suburban gardens.

habitat: It is an inhabitant of the Cerrado. Eggs are laid in subterranean foam nests (sometimes under stones), and the tadpoles are carried by water to puddles and streams. It is not known whether or not it adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Fire and disturbance of the habitat by tourists is a major threat.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: This species occurs on the ground near waterbodies in open areas near forest edge; it is not known from anthropogenically disturbed habitats. It breeds in temporary and permanent pools.
threats: The type locality for this species has been destroyed by infrastructure development and agriculture.
population: It is only known from a few specimens, and was last collected in 1990. A drastic population decline is suspected to have taken place; subsequent searches have not been successful in finding this species, either at the type locality, or elsewhere, and it might now be extinct.

habitat: An inhabitant of the Cerrado savannah, it occurs on the ground near waterbodies, but does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance. The larvae are found in small temporary streams.
threats: The major threats to its habitat are agricultural development (for both the cultivation of crops and the rearing of livestock) and fires.
population: This is a common species.

habitat: It occurs in open areas, on the ground, near waterbodies. It lays its eggs under the ground, and the tadpoles are carried by water to ponds. It adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance (has been collected in Eucalyptus plantations).
threats: Agriculture, extraction (mining), fire and infrastructure development (dams) are all threats.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It occurs in open habitat in grasslands near waterbodies. The larvae are found in streams running down the hillsides.
threats: Threats to this species are unknown.
population: The current population status is not known.

habitat: It is a typical fossorial and seasonal frog, well adapted to a semi-arid continental climate. It inhabits savannah and grassland habitats in the Cerrado biome, and occurs on the ground near standing and temporary waterbodies, such as ponds and swamps, where it also breeds. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: The spread of intensive agriculture in the Cerrado biome is presumably affecting local populations of this species.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It lives on the ground near permanent and temporary bodies of water in the savannah habitats of the Cerrado and Pantanal. It breeds in permanent and temporary pools. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: The spread of intensive agriculture in the Cerrado biome is presumably affecting local populations of this species.
population: It is not an uncommon species.

habitat: It lives on the ground in rocky fields, and probably does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance. It presumably breeds in water, although this has not been confirmed.
threats: This species is possibly affected by fire, expanding human settlements, and disturbance resulting from tourism.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat: It is a species that is found in shrubland and grassland, which breeds in temporary puddles or swamps where it makes floating foam nests. It probably does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: It is possibly affected by fire, expanding human settlements, and disturbance resulting from tourism.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat:
Physalaemus marmoratus breeds in temporary shallow ponds of open habitats. Males call floating on the water with the large vocal sac inflated. During the axillary amplexus a foam nest is constructed on the water surface where the unpigmented eggs are deposited (Nascimento et al., 2006).

It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: There are no major threats, although agricultural activities could be a threat in eastern Paraguay, and probably also in parts of Brazil.
population: This is an uncommon species.

habitat: It is a species of Cerrado savannah that reproduces in temporary or permanent streams.
threats: It might be affected by fire, and by disturbance resulting from tourism.
population: It is not common.

habitat: It lives in open habitats in Cerrado savannah. There is no information on whether or not it adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance. It breeds in streams.
threats: It populations are believed to be impacted by expanding agriculture, overgrazing by domestic livestock, wood extraction, and fire.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It lives in open, grassy areas around temporary ponds, in which it presumably breeds. It adapts to some anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: It might be affected by fire, expanding human settlements, and disturbance resulting from tourism.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat: It lives in Cerrado savannah, occurring in open areas, and breeding in somewhat wet, marshy areas, and temporary pools. It adapts well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Local populations are probably impacted by the spread of intensive, commercial agriculture, as well as by fire and dam construction.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: It lives in rocky, rupestrian open areas on wet rock walls near streams or water falls. The egg clutch is deposited in rock fissures. The tadpoles live on wet rock walls where water the water drains.
threats: There is little information, but it is potentially affected by fire, and by disturbance resulting from tourism. In view of the declines observed in some of the species of Thoropa in southeastern Brazil, this species should be monitored for possible future population collapses, perhaps due to chytridiomycosis.
population: It is a common species is its relatively small range.

habitat: It lives in open areas in savannahs in the Chaco and Cerrado biomes, and also in the Chiquitano dry forests of Bolivia. It is normally associated with temporary waterbodies and flooded areas in forests, grasslands, fields, where it breeds. It appears to adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance.
threats: Certain populations might be impacted by fires and the spread of intensive agriculture, but overall, this species is not significantly threatened.
population: It is a common species.

habitat: This species occurs in Cerrado habitat. Reproductive activity was observed between December and March, in permanent ponds in open areas.
threats: The Cerrado has historically been altered through shifting agriculture, but is now being heavily impacted by large-scale cattle ranching, soy, corn, and irrigated rice.
population: No information is currently available.

habitat: Individuals were found during the day in rocky grasslands sheltered under rocks, moss, fallen logs, arum leaves, and within bromeliad rosettes, close to temporary puddles, ponds and swamps, as well as in backwaters of temporary streams surrounded by vegetation. These varied aquatic habitats comprise the breeding habitat. Males call at night, from shrubby vegetation and occasionally on the ground, throughout the rainy season (October-March), and also during the dry season if there is water available for larval development. Clutches of about 400 eggs are placed on the bottom of water bodies, usually on submerged vegetation. The larvae are diurnal and live in aquatic habitats with abundant aquatic vegetation.
threats: No information is currently available on the threats to this species.
population: Its population status is not known.

habitat: Little is known about the ecology, behaviour or life history of this species. Predators include the Barn Owl (Tyto alba). Members of Carterodon have been found in vegetation types such as grass, shrubs, and cerradáo (a forest savannah dominated by trees above ca. 8 m in height). This species is rarely encountered (Bezerra and Bonvicino 2015). This species inhabits the Cerrado biome, with an apparent association with the more open formations such as campo úmido, campo limpo, campo sujo, and campo cerrado. The species is semi-fossorial and herbivorous based upon few observations and the morphology of the dentition.
threats: Most of the 11 known localities for Carterodon are localities that have been highly impacted by disturbance, including agricultural expansion, pastures, urbanization, and the construction of hydroelectric dams. The entire core area of the Cerrado is undergoing rapid conversion. A number of these localities have no recent capture records, and other localities are now altered or disturbed. The 11 historical localities do not all retain populations of this species. The Red List for the State of Minas Gerais (Machado et al. 1998) considers that the species is likely to be extinct in the state, which includes two known localities and a significant proportion of suitable habitat.
population: The population status of this species is not known.

habitat: The typical habitats of this species are open interfluvial savannas and grasslands in the Cerrado region (Valdujo et al. 2009, Nogueira et al. 2010, Sousa et al. 2010, Recoder et al. 2011), and in its contact areas with the Chaco and Atlantic Forest (Passos and Fernandez 2008, Giraudo et al. 2012). It can persist in pasture and other agricultural areas. It is a viviparous species with a seasonal reproductive cycle, and females give birth to between 8 and 22 neonates per litter (Pizzatto and Marques 2007). It preys on birds and small mammals (Cassimiro et al. 2010).
threats: In Argentina the species is threatened by habitat loss due to urbanization, agricultural expansion, and exotic tree plantations (Giraudo et al. 2012). In the Cerrado region it may be threatened by the extensive habitat loss caused by the expansion of mechanized agriculture (Nogueira et al. 2010). Nevertheless, at least 50% of the range in Brazil was covered in original vegetation based on land use data for 2008 and this species exhibits a degree of tolerance to disturbed areas.
population: This is a moderately frequently-encountered species in central Brazil (Nogueira et al. 2010).

habitat: This species is found in Cerrado habitats (Albuquerque and Lema 2012, Entiauspe-Neto et al. 2014), and possibly in the Pantanal (Albuquerque and Lema 2012).
threats: There are no major threats affecting the species (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
population: The species is common at the known Paraguayan locality. Its scarcity in scientific collections is probably due to inappropriate sampling techniques (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).

habitat: There is "no detailed field data" on the ecology of this recently-resurrected species, but thee known localities are in the central portion of the Cerrado and its contact zone with the Atlantic Forest (Nogueira et al. 2019).
threats: No major threats are thought to exist to this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.

habitat: This species is known from the Cerrado, but there is no detailed information on its ecology (Nogueira et al. 2019).
threats: Most of this species' known limited range is affected by the conversion of native vegetation to pastureland. Around the Manso reservoir, one of the known localities, an increase in land speculation for real estate developments is likely to affect this species.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species. It appears to be common within Chapada dos Guimarães National Park.

habitat: This fosssorial species is found in the western area of Cerrado where it comes into contact with the Chaco (Lema et al. 2005), and in Atlantic Forest of Alto Paraná (Cacciali and Motte 2007). It inhabits open areas and lives in natural underground galleries (usually formed by the death of tree roots or by underground streams) or burrows excavated by mammals and amphisbaenians. It feeds on insect larvae, worms and other invertebrates living in these galleries, and is itself prey for coral snakes (Lema et al. 2005).
threats: There are no major threats affecting the species (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
population: The species is common. Its scarcity in scientific collections is probably due to the use of inappropriate sampling techniques (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).

habitat: Ocorre primariamente em áreas de Cerrado em sua porção mais meridional e floresta estacional e ombrófila (Condez et al. 2009. Sawaya et al. 2008. Bérnils 2009. Hueck and Seibert 1972. IBGE 1992. Costa et al. 2007) em altitudes de até 950m (Altinópolis SP; Bérnils 2009). Pode ser encontrada em áreas alteradas (Sawaya et al. 2008). É fossorial e já foi observada ativa durante o dia e durante a noite (Sawaya et al. 2008. Condez et al. 2009). É ovípara com ciclo reprodutivo sazonal e vitelogênese secundária entre agosto e fevereiro; ovos foram encontrados nos ovidutos em dezembro e a cópula provavelmente ocorre ao redor de novembro (C. Herédias-Ribas R. J. Sawaya com. pess. 2008). Os machos atingem a maturidade sexual com no mínimo 481mm e as fêmeas com 513mm (Herédias-Ribas and Sawaya). De duas fêmeas que apresentaram ovos, uma delas apresentou três e a outra 7 ovos (C. Herédias-Ribas com. pess. 2008). Alimenta-se de cecílias (Marques et al. 2009). Atinge 1262mm de CRC (Sawaya et al. 2008).
threats: Não são conhecidas ameaças que possam levar a espécie aalgum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: This species is found in Chaco habitats. It is a diurnal species that inhabits dry forests and savanna, being found both in trees and on the ground. Like other species of the genus, it likely feeds on amphibians, lizards, and rodents. It has oviparous reproduction (Leynaud and Bucher 1999).
threats: Localized threats include deforestation for agricultural development, but this widespread species is not considered to be at significant risk.
population: This species in uncommon, or at least not often found.

habitat: This species has been observed in savannah, Chaco shrubland and disturbed areas (Strüssmann and Sazima 1993, Silva Jr. and Sites 1999, Sousa et al. 2010). It is primarily associated with seasonal wetlands (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020).
threats: This species has a wide range in an area where human impacts are relatively localized (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020). This species is preferentially associated with seasonal wetlands in the Pantanal which are not well-suited to human occupation and remain relatively pristine (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020).
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.

habitat: This species is endemic to the Cerrado savanna formation. It may use burrows and cavities in termite mounds. It feeds mainly on mammals and lizards but also eats centipedes, frogs, other snakes and birds; showing an ontogenetic dietary shift from ectotherms to endotherms (Valdujo et al. 2002). It is a viviparous snake  (Valdujo et al. 2002)
threats: There are no major threats affecting the species (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
population: It is common throughout its range, but there is no information on population trends.

habitat: It inhabits lowland rainforests. Based on information from congeners it is presumed to be a fossorial species that can be found within leaf litter, breeds in ponds and has aquatic larvae (Toledo et al. 2011).
threats: There is no information on major threats to this species.
population: It was described from 10 individuals captured in 2008 (Caramaschi 2010). There is no information on the population status of this species.

habitat: It inhabits lowland rainforests. Based on information from congeners it is presumed to be a fossorial species that can be found within leaf litter, breeds in ponds and has aquatic larvae (Toledo et al. 2011).
threats: There is no direct information on major threats to this species, although given its widespread occurrence it is possible that there may be localized threats in the form of human settlement development, agriculture, livestock farming and logging.
population: It is known only from the type series. Its population status is currently unknown.

habitat:
This bat lives in caves in dry forests associated with calcareous outcrops and appears to require caves to roost. In a study, population sizes changed throughout the year; the population of Dois Irmãos cave was larger in September and October, probably due to the recruitment of young, and in March and April, due to the return of pregnant females. In all populations the number of females exceeded that of males and the number of adults was greater than that of young. The species is closely associated with karstic environments (Aguiar et al. 2010).

Young individuals were captured from July to November and adults were captured throughout the year. Lonchophylla dekeyseri occurred in relatively small populations and demonstrated fidelity to the shelter, remaining for at least one year in the same cave (Aguiar et al. 2006). The reproductive pattern presented by the species was seasonal monoestry, with young being born in the dry season, probably due to the greater food availability at this time of the year. A nursery system seems to occur, as the females were never observed carrying their young (Aguiar et al. 2006). Females were found to occur in greater numbers than males, suggesting harem formation. Emergence from the shelter occurred in the first hours after dusk; returning just before dawn during the rainy season and returning around midnight and just before dawn during the dry season. The activity pattern observed was unimodal, changing to bimodal in the dry season. Activity period could be related to the blossoming and nectar production patterns of the flowers visited by L. dekeyseri.

It is a nectarivorous bat, but can use other resources such as fruits and insects. Lonchophylla dekeyseri feeds upon pollen in the dry season, when this resource is more plentiful, and consumes more insects and fruits in its diet during the rainy season, when nectar is scarce and insects are abundant. Bat hair analysis showed 7 types of pollen, mainly from Pseudobombax sp., Bauhinia sp. and Lafoensia sp. This species pollinates typical plants of the Cerrado. Bat-pollinated plants flowered during the dry season with sequencial peaks, probably a mechanism which may avoid competition for pollinators by other plants maximizing pollinator efficiency. The occurrence of more than one type of pollen in the same bat hair sample was common, indicating visits to several plant species during only one night (Coelho 1998).
threats: The species distribution is patchy as cerrado habitat is severely and rapidly being degraded and destroyed. Calcereous soils are among the most threatened. The species requires caves to roost and is thus associated with karstic environments which are threatened by mining. Roosts are also threatened by rabies control programs.
population: This species is endemic to one of the most threatened biomes of Brazil, and is expected to decline in response to increasing habitat destruction. Between September 1997 to August 1998, Coelho (1998) captured 152 specimens in 46 nights in three caves located in the Apa do Cafuringa, in the northwestern region of the Federal District of Brazil. The populations appear to be patchily distributed. It is known from six large subpopulations totalling almost 2,500 individuals, but with less than 100 mature adults on each (Aguiar et al. 2006).

habitat: Lonchophylla bokermanni is a medium-sized nectar-feeding bat, and similarly, to its congeners may probably eat fruits and insects to complement its diet. The species is a nectarivore, it pollinates typical plants of the Cerrado, such as Bauhinia rufa (Sazima et al. 1978) and Encholirium glaziovii (Sazima et al. 1989). It is probably dependent of shelters associated with karstic regions. It roosts in small colonies of two to five individuals (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
threats: The geographic range and area of occurrence, the Cerrado region, are severely fragmented and the species is known to exist at no more than five localities. The fragmentation of habitat is continuous and there is a presumed decline in the extent and quality of L. bokermanni habitat in recent years.
population: <span lang="EN-US">Only a few individuals from the three localities, cited in the published papers are computed to the region of the species occurrence, indicating it must be rare in inventories, contributing with few individuals in the known samples to date. Since the description of this species in 1978, it has not been recorded in Minas Gerais (cerrado) despite surveys (Aguiar and Marinho-Filho pers. comm).

habitat: This species seems to prefer moderately disturbed habitats (Anderson 1982). It is found in a variety of habitats, including lowland and montane forest and Cerrado (de la Sancha et al. 2007, Gettinger et al. 2011). No information is available on habits, behaviour, diet or reproduction (Anderson 1997).
threats: There are no major threats to this species. However, local habitat destruction might be reducing the size of some subpopulations.
population: This species is estimated to be widespread with locally low densities.

habitat: Its habitat and ecology is poorly known. It is found in savannah scrub and may require specific habitats, such as Cerrado Rupestre. Further studies are required to determine whether the species occurs in other habitats. It is found in rocky outcrops at higher elevations and on plateaus. Available habitats are patchy (Weklser pers. comm.).
threats: There are no major threats to the species at this time. The species' specific habitat is not highly threatened (although fires may affect some areas); however, surrounding areas are heavily used (Lacher pers. comm.).
population: There is no information on population trends or abundance. The species has been collected rarely as there is a potential problem with the trapping techniques used in surveys undertaken so far (Weksler pers. comm.).

habitat: The species is associated with seasonally dry tropical forest in the Cerrado regions of Brazil, where it occurs in rocky limestone outcrops, emerging to climb and forage on trees (Lacher 2016). It is restricted to the Brazilian Cerrado (A. Langguth pers. comm.). Some specimens have been collected from rocky habitats, where it nests in rock crevices; it is vegetarian, feeding primarily on cacti, manioc and leaves (Moojen et al. 1997). It is reported to be an active and acrobatic animal (Moojen et al. 1997).
threats: Threats to this species are presently unknown. As a large species, it is possible that it is affected by hunting pressure (Lacher 2016), but this requires confirmation.
population: The distribution and population is based upon 14 known specimens (Bezerra et al. 2010).

habitat: This species is found in open areas of the Cerrado biome, which is known to demonstrate a wide structural complexity of habitats (Bezerra and Bonvicino 2015). It is a semi fossorial, colonial species with diurnal activity confined to savannah areas and their edges (Emerson pers. comm.). In Brazil, three females with single embryos were caught during the period June to December (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). Individuals of this species are predators and dispersers of seeds of the palms Attalea geraensis and Syagrus petraea. Breeding may be seasonal. (Bezerra and Bonvicino 2015).
threats: There are no major threats; however, habitat destruction through conversion to agriculture may affect the species in the southern part of the range (Vieira pers. comm.).
population: This species is patchy distributed but locally abundant (Filho pers. comm.).

habitat: Thrichomys apereoides inhabits xeric and rocky environments in caatinga and cerrado including human modified habitats in which the species can be an important agricultural pest (Fabre 2016, Mares and Ojeda 1982, Mares et al. 1985, Moojen 1952, Streilein 1982a).  Individuals may occupy caves and human dwellings. In Exu, Brazil, T. apereoides is associated primarily with granitic outcroppings (Streilein 1982d). In Bolivia, T. apereoides inhabits flat and arid shrub-dominated habitat devoid of large rocks (Anderson 1997). It is a crepuscular species (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). In Brazil, its reproduction occurs throughout the year with two or three litters of one to six young (average 3.1) produced after a gestation period of 89 days (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). Sexual maturity is reached between seven and nine months (Eisenberg and Redford 1999).
threats: It is hunted for food although the species is not considered to have any major threats in operation throughout its range (Bonvicino and Geise pers. comm.).
population: This species is very common throughout the range (Bonvicino and Geise pers. comm.).

habitat: The species inhabits in open vegetation in cerrado and transition areas, forest edge and grassland (Lacher pers. comm.). Individuals occur in dry forest patches, including among aggregations of Attaleya phalerata palms. In the seasonally wet Pantanal devoid of rocky areas, animals have been caught in traps set in trees placed 1.5 m above the ground during the rainy season (Fabre 2016).
threats: There are no major threats to this species at this time.
population: This rodent is common and abundant throughout the range (C. Bonvicino pers. comm.).

habitat: This species occurs in forest lands above 1,000 m all and is present at the border between Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (Leite pers. comm.). In one study males were predominantly captured in the dry season and females in equal numbers in both dry and rainy seasons (Cordeiro and Talamoni 2006, Pessôa et al. 2015).
threats: The major threats are deforestation and destruction of habitat; also, there are frequent fires in its range.
population: This rodent is not commonly found.

habitat: Specimens of this species have been found in forests that ranged from evergreen riverine to deciduous and semideciduous forest and pampa. These environments consisted of both non-flooded and seasonally flooded habitats. threats: The major threats to this species are unknown.
population: There is no information concerning the populations of this species.

habitat: This species occurs in wet grassland, grass and shrubs (Patton and Emmons 2015). It can be found in transition zones between sylvan and pastoral environments of the cerrado, which includes wet and mixed grassland, shrub and low trees. This species has a long tail and moderately long feet, making it presumably adapted to both sylvan and more pastoral habitats (Paresque and Hanson 2015).
threats: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is threatened by its restricted occurunce (Patton and Emmons 2015)"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15247,"3":{"1":0},"4":{"1":2,"2":14543863},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":10207974}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":10207974}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":2,"11":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">This species is threatened by its restricted distribution (Patton and Emmons 2015). Its habitat has been heavily degraded within its small extant of occurrence, and remaining potential habitat is severely fragmented.
population: Populations of this species are poorly known. There have not been any efforts to trap this species recently (E. Vieira pers. comm). It is restricted to two sites in where it occurs (Patton and Emmons 2015). The restricted distribution, combined with the low incidence of capture despite frequent collection efforts over the years, suggests that M. transitorius is a rare species (Paresque and Hanson 2015).

habitat: This species is found on the borders of gallery forest, Cerrado (Bonvicino et al. 2003). Fagundes et al. (2000) found the species in transitional areas between Amazonian rain forest and Cerrado. No information available on the reproductive activity (Bonvicino pers. comm.).
threats: Habitat destruction is occurring throughout its range (except in protected areas) (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
population: No information is available on this species, although other species in the genus are common (Bonvicino et al. 2003). Although the species has been collected only from three localities, this is due to limited sampling (Bonvicino pers. comm.).

habitat: Specimens have been captured in seasonally flooded semi-deciduous forests (Percequillo et al. 2008) and in periodically flooded grasslands along streams in the Cerrado (Bonvicino 2003). Pregnant females were captured in both dry and rainy seasons, suggesting that breeding takes place throughout the year; embryo counts range from two to four (Percequillo 2015).
threats: The major threats to this species are agriculture expansion, cattle and the growing soybean agroindustry.
population: This species is locally common (Bonvicino pers. comm).

habitat: This species is tolerant to habitat modification including agricultural areas (Langguth and Bonvicino 2002). A sample—previously attributed to C. andersoni now a synonym—was collected in a transitional mosaic between dense and high savanna, with open forest. Ground cover was a mixture of dead leaves and 30-40% of grass cover.
threats: Threats to some populations include agricultural expansion, cattle, and soybeans.
population: This species is very common (Langguth and Bonvicino 2002).

habitat: This rodent occurs in open grasslands areas, in campo cerrado transition zones (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.). Its distribution is patchy.
threats: Some populations are threatened by habitat destruction and fragmentation (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
population: The species is very difficult to capture in surveys, although it is commonly found in owl pellets (Bonvicino and Marinho-Filho pers. comm.). The species is rare relative to other species in the genus (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).

habitat: This species occurs in a wide range of habitat, including open grasslands, cerrado, and wet grasslands (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
threats: Although habitat destruction is occurring, it is not considered a major threat to this species (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
population: The species is common (Bonvicino pers. comm.).

habitat: This species occurs in cerrado and also gallery forests (Weksler and Bonvicino 2005).
threats: The main threat is deforestation due to agricultural expansion, but the scope and severity is unknown.
population: This species is relatively common. Weksler and Bonvicino (2005) collected only 12 individuals in Chapada dos Veadeiros.

habitat: This rodent is a specialist of high altitude areas characterized by campos rupestre vegetation in the Cerrado Biome (Weksler and Bonvicino 2005).
threats: There are no major threats to this species at this time.
population: This species is rare and occurs in low densities (Weksler and Bonvicino 2005).

habitat: This species is apparently endemic to the Cerrado biodiversity hotspot (Rocha et al. 2012) and occurs in gallery forest.
threats: The main threat is habitat destruction. This species is apparently endemic to the Cerrado biodiversity hotspot which is currently threatened by deforestation and habitat loss (Rocha et al. 2012).
population: Little is known about the population distribution of this species and more information is required (Rocha et al. 2012), but it is likely decreasing due to habitat loss.

habitat: This species has a marked preference for grassland-dominated habitats in the Cerrado and Atlantic Forest. Records from the Atlantic Forest include localities where the forest cover has been significantly altered by human activities, suggesting that this species might be extending its original range, owing to the fragmentation of semideciduous and evergreen forests. Breeding activity is higher during the rainy season for this species and the greatest densities occur during the dry season, when grass seed production is at its peak (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
threats: There is no information available on threats to this species; the two populations occurring in the National Parks are not likely to currently be experiencing any threats.
population: In the Cerrado of central Brazil, local densities appear to be low in relation to those of other sympatric sigmodontines; however, at the few localities where this species has been recorded in the Atlantic Forest, it is as common as the other local rodents (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

habitat: The species is a habitat specialist occurring in wet grasslands. The species is adapted for burrowing and it spends most of the day in underground tunnels, except during the wet season when it moves above ground (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). It feeds on roots and grasses (Eisenberg and Redford 1999).
threats: The major threat is habitat destruction of the grasslands due to agriculture and livestock (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).
population: This species is not common and is patchily distributed (Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).

habitat: Com um tamanho máximo de aproximadamente 77 mm de comprimento rostro cloacal (Gallagher and Dixon 1992), é uma espécie terrícola que habita área abertas do Cerrado, não ocorrendo em matas e cerradão (Gallagher and Dixon 1992, Nogueira 2006). Pode ser encontrada em simpatria com a espécie congenérica, Kentropyx vanzoi, sendo provavelmente segregados em relação à altitude na região da Chapada dos Guimarães e alopatricamente ocupando margens diferentes do rio Araguaia (Nogueira 2006). Possui uma ninhada de em média de quatro ovos (Anjos et al. 2002, Werneck et al. 2009).
threats: Apesar das ameaças identificadas para algumas subpopulações, como a conversão de áreas naturais em pastagem (causando perda de hábitat e da qualidade), estas ameaças não colocam a espécie em risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie, mas Nogueira (2006) relata que a espécie é relativamente comum em áreas onde é encontrada.

habitat: Com um tamanho máximo de aproximadamente 65 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Gallagher and Dixon 1992), é uma espécie terrícola que habita área abertas do Cerrado, principalmente áreas arenosas bem preservadas, próximos a rios e abaixo de 650 metros de altura (Gallagher and Dixon 1992, Vitt and Caldwell 1993, Nogueira 2006). Pode ser encontra em simpatria com a espécie congenérica, Kentropyx paulensis, sendo provavelmente segregadas em relação a altitude na região da Chapada dos Guimarães e alopatricamente ocupando margens diferentes do rio Araguaia (Nogueira 2006). Possui uma ninhada de em média de três ovos (Werneck et al. 2009). Parece possuir dimorfismo sexual em relação à coloração, no qual o macho é mais verde que a fêmea (Vitt and Caldwell 1993). Pouco se sabe sobre suas s características ecológicas, mas podemos supor que sua dieta é baseada em artrópodes, principalmente aranhas, cupins e ortópteros (Vitt and Caldwell 1993).
threats: A região onde a espécie ocorre é denominada Arco do desmatamento (A.C. Lees com. pess. 2014), justamente devido às fortes perturbações que sofre o ambiente (extração de madeira pecuária e agricultura em larga escala principalmente plantação de soja). Observando-se a ferramenta Google Earth Engine (2014), suspeita-se que nos últimos 10 anos essa área tenha sofrido, aproximadamente,  30%  de perda vegetação nativa e dada as características do hábitat onde a espécie efetivamente ocorre (área de ocupação), suspeita-se que tenha havido a mesma taxa de redução populacional. Na Bolívia, parece não haver ameaças particulares a essa espécie.
population: Não há informações relativas a suas subpopulações, porém Vitt e Caldwell (1993) relatam o fácil encontro da espécie na localidade em que estudaram (Vilhena Rondônia). Considerando que 10 anos é maior que três gerações para a espécie e sua especificidade de hábitat, pode-se suspeitar que a redução da população seja equivalente à perda do hábitat.

habitat: Espécie endêmica do Cerrado, pode ser encontrada em áreas de campo sujo ou campo cerrado (Nogueira 2006). Com aproximadamente 400 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal, é endêmica do Cerrado. Poucas informações sobre seus hábitos são encontrados, mas podemos inferir utilizando dados da espécie cogenérica e simpátrica, S. merianae que é diurna de forrageamento ativo, com alimentação generalista, alimentando-se desde plantas e invertebrados até vertebrados e possui uma ninhada de aproximadamente 36 ovos (Yanosky and Mercolli 1992).
threats: A agricultura e a introdução de gramíneas exóticas são grandes ameaças para as áreas isoladas do habitat do cerrado onde esta espécie ocorre (P. Cacciali comm. pes. 2016). Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, não são conhecidas ameaças que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção. O comércio ilegal de peles e animais de estimação representa uma ameaça potencial, embora atualmente não se pense que a demanda seja alta.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. É raramente encontrada. Esta espécie é confinada ao habitat de cerrado distribuído de maneira irregular, que é ainda mais fragmentado pela conversão de habitat, e a população é considerada provável de ser severamente fragmentada no Paraguai (P. Cacciali comm pes. 2016).

habitat: Drymoluber brazili is found mainly within Cerrado habitats, Atlantic Forest, or transition areas between the Cerrado and Caatinga biomes (Costa et al. 2010, Freitas et al. 2012, Costa et al. 2013).
threats: Localized threats like agriculture and cattle grazing may exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population: It is a rare species in Paraguay and there is not much information on population trends (P. Cacciali and N. Scott, pers. comm. 2014). Although it is widespread in Brazil it is poorly-represented in collections in this country, with only 34 museum specimens known (Freitas et al. 2012).

habitat: It is known from rocky mountain meadows (Campo Rupestre), a typical phytophysiognomy of the Espinhaço Range. Adults are known to be active at night, and exhibit preferences towards small temporary rocky streams, wet rock outcrops and in gallery forests of permanent streams (Leite et al. 2011). This species breeds via larval development, with adult males observed calling between November and January (F.S.F. Leite pers. comm. August 2013).
threats: Silviculture is an economic activity that is increasingly common in the region, particularly of Eucalyptus and Pinus monocultures. Populations of endemic anurans in Serra do Cabral are likely to be affected by resulting habitat loss and fragmentation (Leite et al. 2011, F.S.F. Leite pers. comm. August 2013).
population: This species is common within its small range; however, it occurs within fragmented habitat patches and is likely to have poor dispersal ability (F.S.F. Leite pers. comm. August 2013).

habitat: The species is found mostly in grasslands of Cerrado, Pantanal and Chaco habitats. In Brazil and Bolivia the species occurs in grasslands and savannas relatively close to forest or areas of complex habitats between open and forest vegetation (J. Aparicio, L. Gonzales and C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). It can adapt to human habitations in rural habitats in Paraguay (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014). Large number of specimens have been collected after the flooding of one of the hydroelectric reservoirs in Manco, Mato Grosso. It appears to be relatively common in Emas National Park, Goiás and Mato Grosso do Sul, suggesting that this species is locally quite common where natural habitat is well-preserved (T. Avila-Pires pers. comm. 2016, C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2016, Nogueira et al. 2009).
threats: This species is affected by habitat loss due mainly to mechanized agriculture (but at local scales also to flooding for hydroelectric reservoirs) in Brazil, which has resulted in extensive historical and ongoing habitat loss in the Cerrado (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014, 2016), but there are no major threats affecting the species in Bolivia and Paraguay (J. Aparicio, P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
population: While this skink is common in parts of its distribution, it is relatively rare compared with other mabuyine skinks in the Cerrado (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2016). In a study of lizard diversity at ten Cerrado sites in Brazil it was relatively common only at a single locality dominated by tabletop grassland and savanna, in a protected area (Nogueira et al. 2009). Across this study as a whole, only 26 records (of 2,917 lizards recorded) were referrable to this species. Most records in zoological collections represent specimens taken during the filling of hydroelectric reservoirs, where suitable habitat no longer exists (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). Overall, the species is inferred to be declining at least in Brazil as a result of extensive habitat loss (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014, T. Avila-Pires and P. Cacciali pers. comm. 2016).

habitat: It is known to occur in open areas of the Cerrado biome in Campo sujo and Campo limpo habitats (Martins and Giaretta 2011, Brandão et al. 2012). Individuals have been observed calling at night following rain during the summer months of November and December along small seasonal rocky streams (Martins and Giaretta 2011). Breeding is known to occur via egg deposition, whereby eggs are deposited in areas of approximately 30 cm diameter, and subsequently buried within sandy / muddy areas at the bottom of the stream dug by females (Martins and Giaretta 2011).
threats: Although the type locality for this species is within a protected area (PESCAN), the surrounding areas within the Cerrado biome are very degraded, with particular impacts from cattle ranching and plantations. These activities may pose a risk to this species, especially due to the drainage of water sources (L.B. Martins pers. comm. August 2013).
population: It is common within its type locality (L.B. Martins pers. comm. August 2013); however, with exception of the locality within PESCAN, all other known localities are from museum specimens with little information on the populations in these areas (Brandão et al. 2012, L.B. Martins pers. comm. August 2013).

habitat: This species occurs in tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests, where it is found associated with rock outcrops (Carvalho 2013) and exhibits a preference for vertical surfaces (Morais et al. 2014). The Brazilian part of the tableland is characterized by Cerrado vegetation (i.e. mesic savanna). Individuals bask in the sun on rocks during the day and hide under rocks at night. It eats a wide variety of insects such as ants, cicadas and other homopterans, grasshoppers, crickets, beetles, wasps, and moths (Harvey and Gutberlet 1998).
threats: In Bolivia, the area where the species occurs is very remote and well-protected (the Noel Kempf Mercado National Park), and there is no evidence of a decline in habitat extent or quality. In Brazil the species' known locality is nominally protected within the Parque Estudal Serra Ricardo Franco (only partly protected area), however this reserve has not been effectively demarcated and its surroundings have been subject to heavy exploitation for agriculture and logging (Morais et al. 2014). It is unknown to what extent these activities threaten this rock-dwelling lizard, or how far they extend into the larger, Bolivian portion of the tableland where the species may occur.
population: This species has been found to be fairly common in its distinctive and restricted habitat. The Brazilian series consists of 32 individuals taken from three collecting sites (Morais et al. 2014), indicating that it is somewhat abundant and widespread at the top of Serra de Ricardo Franco.

habitat: This species is found in Cerrado habitats (Strüssman and Mott 2009). In Matto Grosso, most known localities lie in transitional areas between Cerrado savanna and Amazonian forest (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2018). There is a single record from Poconé, within the Pantanal, but the species is much more frequently encountered "in areas under southern Amazonia influence" (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2018).
threats: This species is associated with Cerrado savannas, an area under heavy human pressure, but as it is widespread within this area it may not be subject to major range-wide threats (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2018).
population: This species is widespread in Brazil (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2018). It is usually locally abundant (and can be "really abundant") in Matto Grosso, where it is known from 15 localities (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2018).

habitat: This species is found in Cerrado habitats (Strüssman and Mott 2009).
threats: Although any threats to this poorly-known species are not well-understood (P. Cacciali pers. comm. 2014), given its broad distribution it is not thought to be subject to major threats.
population: This is an uncommon species, with only a few specimens recorded throughout its distribution (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). Because of its fossorial habits it may be difficult to collect. Population trends over the past 10 years are uncertain, but in the absence of major threats its abundance has probably been relatively stable.

habitat: The species occurs in Cerrado and Pantanal habitats (Nogueira et al. 2003, Campbell and Lamar 2004). It is typically found in gallery forest and occasionally in dry inter-fluvial savannas. It preys on rodents, frogs, lizards, snakes, birds and centipedes (Nogueira et al. 2003). It can inhabit areas with some degree of habitat degradation caused by human activities (Giraudo et al. 2012).
threats: It is hunted and persecuted by people, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population: It is a common species. There is no information on population trends.

habitat: The type locality of this fossorial species is tropical dry forest on the bank of the Paraguá River, where much of the low-lying surrounding area is seasonally inundated. The species is probably dependent on pristine savannas or woodlands (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2016), and is likely not a forest dweller (G. Colli pers. comm. 2016).
threats: The species is not currently threatened, although it occurs on a private farm where a future change in management practices could negatively affect the species. On the Brazilian side of the Serrania there is growing pressure to degazette the reserve where this snake has been found, to permit large-scale cattle ranching and the establishment of soybean monocultures (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2018). As a fossorial or semifossorial species, changes in soil quality (that are expected if mechanized agriculture develops and expands in the area) will likely produce significant threats. Cerrado soils are quite complex, full of galleries and occupied by many different forms of fossorial and semifossorial squamates. Once mechanized agriculture settles in, soils are deeply affected, all vegetation cover is removed and most natural crevices, burrows and cavities are  eliminated by the use of heavy machinery for ploughing. This species, as with many other Apostolepis species, exhibits a very specialized morphology for burrowing, hunting and hiding in soil crevices, near the surface.
population: The population trend is unknown,but there has been no noticeable change in the habitat for at least several decades.

habitat:
Espécie diurna e noturna, associada a áreas de cerrado rupestre ou cerrado típico, com boa cobertura arbórea e ambientes rochosos e de vegetação aberta quanto em campos abertos, associados a abrigos (Colli et al. 2003, Nogueira 2006, Vitt et al. 2007). Sua dieta é especialista, composta basicamente por cupins, mas com registros de artrópodes e formigas (Colli et al. 2003). Por isto, é plausível acreditar que experimenta condições ambientais mais estáveis e previsíveis quando comparada a espécies de forrageamento mais ativos (Mesquita and Colli 2003).

Possui como características pálpebras fixas, membros pentadáctilos, pupila vertical elíptica, fileiras longitudinais de tubérculos dorsais distribuídos entre grânulos, dedos não dilatados e dotados de garras. Em estudo em duas áreas de Cerrado no Brasil Central (Pellegrino et al. 2009) foi encontrado três diferentes citótipos. Pode atingir até 54,70mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal. Possui dimorfismo sexual, com fêmeas maiores que machos. Apresenta pico reprodutivo na estação seca (Maio a Setembro) e depositam ovos pequenos, mas em grande número por ninhada. Quando apresentava dois folículos ou dois ovos oviductuais, ambos estavam no mesmo estágio de desenvolvimento. Machos reprodutivos ocorrem ao longo do ano (Colli et al. 2003).  Há registro de parasitismo por Spauligodon oxkutzcabiensis (Goldberg et al. 2010).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, causada principalmente pela conversão em pastagem e área cultivada, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção, dada sua ampla distribuição.
population: Não há dados populacionais disponíveis, mas parece ser abundante em diversas localidades.

habitat: Ocorre em matas e campos rupestres. Está associada a rochas. Assim como G. vanzolinii, G. guttulatus é endêmica da Serra do Espinhaço, mas separados por interrupções abruptas ao longo da Cadeia do Espinhaço (Cassimiro and Rodrigues 2009, Junior 2010). Espécie de médio porte. Apresenta manchas escuras e irregulares ao longo do dorso. Alguns indivíduos apresentam pontuações brancas (Cassimiro and Rodrigues 2009, Junior 2010).  É potencial presa de Siphlophis longicaudatus (Alencar et al. 2009).
threats: O fogo, a destruição e a descaracterização e fragmentação das matas e campos rupestres representam as ameaças mais imediatas à conservação da espécie (Martins and Molina 2008). No entanto, não há evidências de que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção, pois a área onde ocorre a espécie tem cerca de 95% de remanescente natural (IBAMA-PMDBBS 2008). Além disso, conforme  as demais espécies desse tipo de ambiente, ela tem adaptações comportamentais para se proteger do fogo (refugiar-se entre as rochas) (M. Martins pers. comm. 2014).
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Localmente abundante (R. Recoder pers. comm. 2014).

habitat: This is a terrestrial species whose diet is predominantly composed of bird's eggs. From its distribution it can be inferred that the dominant habitats within the range of this species are Cerrado and Atlantic forest. This species is thought to have a low level of adaptability to altered habitats (Franca and Araujo 2006).
threats: There has been a high level of habitat degradation within the range of this species as a result of deforestation and conversion of land to agriculture, however, the majority of this habitat loss occurred during the 1960s and ongoing rates of habitat loss are low. In Distrito Federal, Brazil,  Franca and Araujo (2006) found that this species exhibited traits more likely to be vulnerable to extinction, including highly specialized prey and a low level of adaptability to altered habitats, but it remains widespread and ongoing threats are limited.
population: No population data are available for this species.

habitat: This species is found in Cerrado dry forest and mesic savanna habitat. The species occurs on rocky outcrops, and is insectivorous. The species is largely terrestrial and may be heliothermic, having been observed primarily on the ground in direct sunlight in Brazil (Morais et al. 2014). This species does not persist when habitat is converted to intensive agriculture.
