threats: This species is threatened in part of its range, in both Brazil and Bolivia, by intensive agricultural activities (soy plantations and cattle ranching) that have recently been initiated. The Brazilian locality is also surrounded by areas heavily exploited for timber extraction (Morais et al. 2014). This species is considered to be local and dependent on specific habitats and microhabitats. Therefore, it is naturally segregated in localized subpopulations, and this situation may be more serious given impacts at the Brazilian side of the range. (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2016)
population: This species was reported to be common on rocks in sunny areas in the Bolivian localities where this species was collected. The subpopulation in San Ignacio de Velasco is likely declining due to rapid and severe habitat destruction. There is no information on the species' population status in Brazil, where it is known from a series of six specimens from a single collection site, however, it appeared to be much less abundant than the sympatric Tropidurus callathelys and this site, too, is exposed to threats from extensive habitat modification.

habitat: Ocorre no bioma Cerrado. Parece estar associada a áreas abertas e arenosas (Nogueira 2006). Existem relatos da ocupação em áreas de pastagem o que indica sua resistência a ambientes alterados. Espécie de pequeno porte. Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 36 mm nos machos e 41.5 mm nas fêmeas (Recoder et al. 2014). Assim como os outros Gymnophialminii, possui hábitos semifossoriais, é diurno e se alimenta de artrópodes.
threats: No Cerrado diversas áreas são modificadas para a agricultura de soja (especialmente na região da Serra Geral, na porção central da distribuição da espécie) e pecuária em toda sua extensão, No entanto, não há evidências de que essas ameaças possam levar a espécie à extinção.
population: Não há informações sobre suas populações, entretanto nos locais em que ocorre é localmente abundante (Recoder et al. 2014).

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). Ocorre no bioma Cerrado (Silva et al. 2009, Strüssmann et al. 2009).
threats: Não há informações disponíveis sobre ameaças que possam levar a espécie a alguma categoria de risco de extinção. Entretanto, há grande perda de vegetação nativa (desmatamento agricultura mecanizada e implantação de empreendimento imobiliário) na região em que a espécie ocorre.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: This species is found in Cerrados habitats, savannas, rainforest, open areas within transitional dry forest, and open areas within rainforest (Langstroth 2006, P. Cacciali pers comm. 2014). It can also inhabit disturbed areas (Langstroth 2006). It is a terrestrial species usually found at or near the mouth of armadillo or human-made holes and termite mounds (Langstroth 2006).
threats: There are no major threats affecting the species (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
population: It is a common species throughout its distribution, but there is no information on the population trends.

habitat: This species is found in Atlantic Forest and Cerrado habitats (Cacciali et al. 2009). It is a diurnal and terrestrial species that lays eggs and feeds on frogs, lizards and small rodents (Cacciali et al. 2009).
threats: Localized threats like deforestation may exist, but on a range-wide scale no major threats are known.
population: This snake is rare in Paraguay and very common in Brazil. There is no information on population trends.

habitat: Ocorre no domínio do Cerrado (França et al. 2006, Rodrigues and Prudente 2011) e áreas ecotonais entre Cerrado/Caatinga (T. Guedes com. pess. 2012). É terrícola e possui dieta baseada em lagartos (França et al. 2006). Seu período de atividade é diurno (França et al. 2006). É uma serpente que mede cerca de 496 mm de comprimento total (França et al. 2006).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: This is a fossorial species found in the Cerrado habitat. It is only found in interfluvial savannas (C. Nogueira pers. comm.). This species has been found in sandy soils, but it is not necessarily restricted to this substrate
threats: The interfluvial savanna habitat of this species is being converted to agriculture at very high rates across its entire range: it has been estimated that this species' available habitat has been reduced by 50.4% between 1998 and 2008 (C. Nogueira pers. comm.); subsequent rates of habitat loss appear to be lower based on data from Global Forest Watch but still severe. Habitat loss is particularly pronounced in the southern portion Cerrado where this species occurs.
population: This has been considered a rare species, although Colli et al. (1998) note that this fossorial species is likely to be more abundant than collections might indicate based on the results of pitfall trap surveys. Subsequent pitfall trapping in ten Cerrado localities, however, captured only 12 specimens among 2,900 lizard captures overall (Nogueira et al. 2009). Habitat loss throughout the range of the species is probably causing significant reductions in population size, and isolating remaining subpopulations.

habitat: No litoral norte está sempre associada a ambientes em planícies litorâneas alagadas, principalmente áreas de espraiamento de rios e nas principais bacias hidrográficas da região do litoral norte da Bahia. Na Amazônia habita enclaves de cerrado e florestas de transição. É possível que apresente subpopulações disjuntas. Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 55 mm em machos e 49 mm em fêmeas (Avila-Pires 1995).
threats: A grande ameaça sofrida pela espécie é a perda de hábitat. No Cerrado, diversas áreas são modificadas para a agricultura e pecuária e no litoral devido a elevada concentração de complexos hoteleiros e residências que degradam áreas de zona úmida alagadas. Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa, na área de sua distribuição, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: É abundante em áreas de Cerradão da Estação Ecológica da Serra das Araras, no estado do Mato Grosso (R. Valadão com. pess. 2013).

habitat: This snake is found in central Brazilian Cerrado savannas and grasslands, around the upper Paraná basin (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). The species is restricted to areas dominated by open grassland formations (campo limpo and campo sujo), generally developing over gently rolling, elevated table-tops (locally known as Chapadas) (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). These habitats tend to occur in isolated tabletops with flat or gently rolling terrain. In Paraguay in this species has been found in a patch of well preserved Cerrado, in the highly deforested San Pedro Department (P. Cacciali pers. comm. 2016). In the southernmost part of its range in São Paulo state, Brazil, the dominant habitat is mixed deciduous forest, however, most of the known collection localities are in or near 'islands' of Cerrado habitat in the state (C. Nogueira pers. comm.).
threats: This species is endemic to the most heavily impacted and fragmented region of the Cerrado grassland and savanna region, the plateaus of the upper Paraná basin (C. Nogueira pers. comm.). It is likely to be impacted by habitat destruction throughout its range. Throughout its range, typical grassland habitats are extremely fragmented due to ongoing habitat loss, caused by the irreversible conversion of Cerrado grasslands for agriculture, grazing and human development (WWF 2007, C. Nogueira pers. comm.). Based on satellite data from the Ministerio do Meio Ambiente, it has been estimated that in 1998, only 18% of the original Cerrado habitat was available; this dwindled to only 16% in 2008 (C. Nogueira pers. comm.). An average habitat loss rate of 44% per ten-year period has been estimated (C. Nogueira pers. comm.), and rates of habitat loss are likely to have remained stable or accelerated in the decade since these figures were estimated. Since this species is a grassland specialist, these losses are even more acute. Grasslands are generally the first habitats to be converted, due to the lack of formal protection and the suitability for agricultural development.
population: This is a rarely-collected species known from a "handful" of specimens almost all from the Brazilian Cerrado (Smith et al. 2014), and is thought to be genuinely rare. In Emas National Park in Goiás more than 500 snake specimens were sampled, with only three individuals of this species recorded. Intensive sampling in a Cerrado reserve in São Paulo state, where historical records are available (pre-1980), failed to record this species (Sawaya et al. 2008). A population decline is inferred based on extensive habitat loss throughout the range of this species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). This species occurs, or occurred historically, in one of the most heavily surveyed areas of Brazil and has been subjected to targeted searches (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). While most workers expect that it will be rediscovered in parts of its historical range, C. Nogueira (pers. comm. 2019) suggests that the absence of recent records from anywhere else in its Brazilian range despite extensive surveys implies that it may no longer survive in São Paulo or Goias.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e hábitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). A espécie pode chegar a aproximadamente 300 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Vanzolini 1991).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa (agricultura mecanizada), na área de distribuição da espécie, não há evidências de que possa levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Trata-se de espécie de difícil encontro (rara).

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). A espécie pode atingir até 264 mm de comprimento total (Pinna et al. 2010). Parece ocorrer em áreas de Cerrado arenoso, porém tanto o holótipo quanto o parátipo foram emcontrados nas proximidades de uma plantação de Pinus sp. (Pinna et al. 2010). É espécie de difícil encontro.
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa, na área de distribuição da espécie, devido a expansão da agricultura mecanizada, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). As espécies do gênero Leposternon possuem sempre a cabeça dorsoventralmente comprimida. A espécie pode chegar até 317 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Ribeiro et al. 2008).
threats: Destaca-se que a localidade tipo foi alagada pelo enchimento do reservatório da Usina Hidrelétrica de Espora e é possível que esteja sofrendo redução da população em decorrência da perda de hábitat (agricultura mecanizada desmatamento para implantação de empreendimento imobiliário).
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Faltam informações sobre tamanho/estrutura, tendências e distribuição da população.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). A espécie pode atingir até 316 mm de comprimento total (Silva et al. 2010). Sua dieta inclui uma grande gama de itens alimentares, entre eles formigas, besouros e gafanhotos (Strüssmann and Carvalho 2001). É ovípara e ninhada de até dois ovos (Strüssmann and Carvalho 2001).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, em decorrência de desmatamento, agricultura mecanizada e implantação de empreendimento imobiliário e hidrelétricas, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961).
threats: As principais ameaças a espécie são a construção de usinas hidrelétricas e a perda de vegetação nativa por conta do desmatamento, agricultura mecanizada e implantação de empreendimento imobiliário. No entanto, não há evidências de que essas ameaças coloquem a espécie em risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). As espécies do gênero Leposternon possuem sempre a cabeça dorsoventralmente comprimida. A espécie pode chegar até 418 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Ribeiro et al. 2012).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, em decorrência da agricultura mecanizada, não há evidências de que essa atividade esteja levando a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: It occurs in montane rock fields with sandy/muddy soil, or lowland grassy fields with sandy/muddy soil that are almost always associated with palm grove marshes (“veredas”). Males call within underground chambers or from exposed calling sites, most times among grassy tufts. The species is mainly active during the night, but males may also be heard during daylight or at dusk in rainy days (De Carvalho and Giaretta 2013, Araújo et al. 2015). Similar to its congeners, it is expected to breed by larval development. It is unclear as to whether or not it is tolerant of habitat disturbance.
threats: There are no major threats to this species.
population: It is a widespread and abundant species. The population trend is considered to be stable.

habitat: Little is known about the ecology of this species. Specimens were captured primarily in ipucas, seasonally flooded forest fragments, and both on the ground and in the understory. Adult females were lactating when captured in September (Tribe 2015).
threats: There are no known threats to this species.
population: No population data available.

habitat: This terrestrial species inhabits riparian shrub within the savannahs of the Cerrado biome. Males were found calling at night (19:30–20:00) during the rainy months (November–December) and on the ground between small shrubs, at the margin of a small, seasonal rocky stream (Godinho et al. 2013). Seventeen tadpoles were collected in January from a stream at the type locality indicating that this species reproduces by larval development (Peixoto et al. 2014)
threats: Satellite imagery between 1980–2020 shows extensive land use changes in the region. The species occurs in a vast area of intensive agriculture where the native habitat has largely been converted to pasture, crop cultivation, and even urban areas and mining (Haddad et al. 2016). Related activities, including the use of fire to create and maintain fields, and the negative impacts of the use of agrichemicals, are presumed to be additional threats to the species.
population: Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.

habitat: This arboreal species is endemic to the Cerrado biome where it occurs in gallery forests, but descends to the forest floor and streams for breeding. It has been observed congregating around a muddy section of a stream at the forest edge. Males were heard calling late at night (around 01:00) through midday on the following day. Males call from the ground or perched on low (<1 m) vegetation. Egg clutches are laid 5–10 cm deep and hidden among dead leaves underwater. The average number of eggs per clutch is 637 (Carvalho et al. 2012). The tadpoles develop in the water.
threats: The RPPN-Galheiro is on the shore of a large reservoir created on the Rio São João for the Nova Ponte hydroelectric power station. In terms of ongoing threats, this region of Minas Gerais is intensively farmed thanks to this reservoir and other rivers. The landscape within and between the municipalities of Perdizes and São Gotardo is filled with cattle ranches and cultivated fields, both of which are maintained through seasonal application of fire (Giaretta et al. 2007).
population: Due to the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat, its population is inferred to be decreasing.

habitat:
Hoary Foxes are typically found in open Cerrado, apparently preferring areas with sparse vegetation such as campos limpos, campos sujos, campos cerrados and cerrado sensu stricto (Cabrera and Yepes 1960, Coimbra-Filho 1966, Dalponte 1997, 2003, Silveira 1999, Juarez and Marinho-Filho 2002). Despite apparently avoiding swamp or flooded regions, it can be found in some open and dry lands in the Pantanal during the flooding period (Dalponte 2003). Censuses conducted in flooded lowlands of the Paraguay river did not record the species, neither in low continuous areas (Alho etal. 1988) nor in high, isolated areas (Schaller 1983, Dalponte 2003). There are records in human-modified areas such as pastures (Courtenay et al. 2006, Rocha et al. 2008, Dalponte 2009, Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011), agriculture (Juarez and Marinho-Filho 2002, Dalponte 2003, Lemos and Azevedo, obs. pes.) and silviculture, specifically in recent plantations of eucalyptus (Courtenay et al. 2006) and rubber (Lemos and Azevedo, pers. obs.). According to Dalponte (2003), cattle ranching areas (managed and in recomposition) represented 24.5% of Hoary Fox records by direct observation, while cultivated areas represented 7.5% of the records. In cattle farms in south-eastern Goiás, Lemos, Facure et al. (2011) observed, via radio-telemetry, that Hoary Foxes utilized more pasture areas (especially trampled and overgrazed pastures) compared with other available habitats (pastures in some stage of succession, semi-deciduous vegetation and their edges, and swamps and their edges). There were no records in forest areas.

The Hoary Fox is an omnivore that uses termites as the basis of its diet in addition to beetles and grasshoppers, and depending on environment and season, wild and exotic fruits, small mammals, lizards, snakes, anurans and birds (Dalponte 1995, Dalponte 1997, Dalponte and Lima 1997, Juarez and Marinho-Filho 2002, Jácomo et al. 2004, Ferreira-Silva and Lima 2006, Trovati et al. 2006, Dalponte 2009, Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Kotviski et al. in press). When it occurs in sympatry with the Crab-eating Fox and Maned Wolf (Chrysocyon brachyurus), there is some degree of interspecific dietary overlap (Jácomo et al. 2004; Kotviski et al. in press). However, the primarily termite-based diet of the Hoary Fox apparently allows it to coexist with other canids (Dalponte 2009, Kotwiski et al. in press). Some moderate diet overlap between C. thous and L. vetulus has been observed, although there were some differences in their preference for food items (Silveira 1999, Juarez and Marinho-Filho 2002, Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Kotviski et al. in press). Jácomo and collaborators (2004) analysed the overlap in trophic niches among the three species at Emas National Park in Goiás and the largest overlap was between the Maned Wolf and the Hoary Fox. However, both species differed in their activity patterns, which allows them to co-exist sympatrically.

Hoary Foxes are considered solitary (Dalponte 2009) and monogamous, forming reproductive pairs during the breeding season and having offspring care (Dalponte 2003, Courtenay et al. 2006, Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Lemos 2016). Direct observations report social interactions between the members of the familial group (male, female and season offspring), with more intense contact between males and females during the first four months of the offspring life. Females generate litters of one to five offspring (mean = 3, often born between July and August), with a gestation period of approximately 50 days (Dalponte 2003, Dalponte 2009, Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Lemos and Azevedo, pers. obs.). Juvenile dispersal occurs between nine and ten months of age, when they begin to establish their own territories, which can be close to the area of their first months of life (Dalponte 2003, Lemos and Azevedo, pers. obs.).

There are few studies about home-range patterns. In Bahia, Juarez and Marinho-Filho (2002) estimated the home-range of an adult female at 3.8 km2 while that of a juvenile male was 2 km2. Courtenay et al. (2006) followed a pair and two cubs in a human-modified area in Minas Gerais for a few months and estimated a family home-range of 4.56 km2. In Mato Grosso two pairs monitored for seven months had home-ranges of approximately 2 km² (Dalponte et al. 2018). In south-eastern Goiás, in human-modified areas of pasture in Cumari, Hoary Foxes (n = 12 males and eight females) monitored between 2008 and 2016 had an average home-range of 2.77 km2 (Lemos 2016). Due to the low number of monitored populations (both in natural and human-modified areas) and the short duration of most studies, medium and long-term population studies are necessary. 

Regarding interspecific interactions, there are very few studies about encounters between the Hoary Fox and other carnivores. From 2005 to 2016, in south-eastern Goiás, Lemos et al. (pers. obs.) witnessed at least six encounters between Hoary Foxes and Crab-eating Foxes/Maned Wolves, which generally resulted in the larger species chasing the smaller one (Lemos et al. 2007, Lemos 2016). Three records consisted of observations of Hoary Foxes monitored via radio-telemetry being expelled from their areas by monitored Crab-eating Foxes. Lemos, Facure et al. (2011) also reports one male Hoary Fox with aggressive behaviour repelling a Maned Wolf from a den. There are very limited data with respect to predation by large carnivores, although Jácomo et al. (2004) registered Hoary Fox fur in Maned Wolf scats and R.C. de Paula (pers. obs.) and C. Bickley (pers. comm.) recorded Maned Wolves pursuing Hoary Foxes at Serra da Canastra National Park and south-eastern Goias, respectively. In south-eastern Goiás, 24% of the mortality in a monitored population (N = 40 Hoary Foxes) was due to predation by Pumas Puma concolor (Lemos 2016).
threats:
The major threats to the Hoary Fox are habitat destruction and other direct and indirect anthropogenic effects (Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011, Lemos et al. 2013, Lemos 2016). The species is endemic to the Cerrado, which was historically seen as unproductive land. However, extensive commercial and industrial development in the region over the last two decades, characterized by growth (in size and number) of urban centres, increased timber exploitation for coal provision, conversion of natural habitats to pastures and crops, and the expansion of linear structures for transportation of rural products has resulted in loss and fragmentation of the original Cerrado habitats (Dalponte 2003, Lemos and Azevedo 2009, Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011, Lemos et al. 2013). Natural Cerrado areas in São Paulo and Minas Gerais occur in small and scattered fragments, and are currently isolated from the northern, more continuous portion of the biome.

Road kills are responsible for a high number of individuals being lost from populations (Dalponte 2003, Dalponte and Courtenay 2004, Lemos and Azevedo, 2009, Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011, Lemos 2016), followed by attacks by domestic dogs and human persecution in response to an erroneous perception that Hoary Foxes attack domestic fowl (Dalponte 2003, Lemos and Azevedo 2009, Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011, Lemos et al. 2013, Bickley et al. in press). In fact, domestic fowl are mostly absent from the Hoary Fox diet (Lemos, Facure et al. 2011, Kotviski et al. in press). During population monitoring (n = 40 individuals) in Cumari, south-eastern Goiás, 29 Hoary Fox carcasses were retrieved, with the cause of mortality identified as: road-kills (n = 5), attacks by domestic dogs (n = 1), poisoning/gunshot (n = 3), predation by cougars (n = 7) and old age (n = 1). Mortality causes for 12 individuals were impossible to determine, but it is possible that diseases may have played a role.

Increasing contact between Hoary Foxes and humans and domestic animals may be leading to the development of novel eco-epidemiologic relationships as observed in Cumari (Goiás state). Hoary Foxes are frequently observed foraging among cattle and in close contact with human residences, and involved in antagonistic encounters with domestic dogs (Lemos, Azevedo et al. 2011). An infection of canine distemper virus (CDV) has been reported in a wild Hoary Fox and the potential sources of infection were domestic dogs (Megid et al. 2010). This report highlights the susceptibility of the species to CDV, with clinical and hystopathological signs identical to those developed by domestic dogs. There are also reports of two individuals that tested positive for canine parvovirus (Curi 2005). In the past, Hoary Foxes were identified as reservoirs of Leishmania chagasi (Deane and Deane 1954). However, Courtenay et al. (1996) compared craniums and demonstrated that infected individuals were in fact misidentified Crab-eating Foxes. There are no reports of rabies for the species. Hoary Foxes of two populations sampled in Cumari (Goiás) and Araguari (Minas Gerais) showed positive seroprevalence for Trypanosoma cruzi (71%) and Leptospira spp. (14.2%). However, parasites were not isolated, and there were no parasitemia cases nor clinical signs. Therefore, clinical and epidemiological importance of these parasites for Hoary Foxes is still unclear (Rocha et al. 2013, Rodrigues et al. 2015). Consequently, long-term studies to elucidate the susceptibility of this species to pathogens and understand the effects of these parasites on the survival of populations in natural and human-modified areas across its range are urgently needed.
population:
Only two studies have previously estimated population densities of the Hoary Fox. Rocha et al. (2008) used linear transects at two locations in Mato Grosso and estimated 1.21 individuals per km² in an area covered by shrub savannah and 4.28 individuals per km² in an exotic grass pasture. However, these estimates should be cautiously interpreted since it is possible that the difference in density is biased by: i) the species' detectability in the different environments, and ii) the timing of sampling in different reproductive seasons. The 4.28 density was estimated in the second semester, when foxes are known to be denning and foraging with puppies together, and this may have overestimated density at the pasture site. Rezende (2018), using capture-recapture models accounting for imperfect detectability, estimated 0.41 individual per km2 in a fragmented area comprising a matrix of exotic pastures in south-eastern Goiás. In the same region/population, Lemos and Azevedo (unpublished data) registered offspring mortality greater than 50% in cohorts monitored during 12 years, with potentially negative demographic impacts.

To estimate the population size of the Hoary Fox, the total area of suitable habitat was determined taking into account remnants of Cerrado habitats (grassland, savannah, and other non-forest), and 50% of the area of pastures, within the species’ current range, yielding an area of approximately 120,000 km². Considering the limited information on density for the species in disturbed and natural habitats (0.41 individual per km², Rezende 2018; 1.21 individuals per km², Rocha et al. 2008), the habitats known to be used and the anthropogenic threats across most of the range, it was estimated that the Hoary Fox population might be approximately 49,200-96,000 individuals (based on a mean density of 0.8 individual per km²). Number of mature individuals may vary according to species life stories, degree of habitat specificity, mortality rates, and how isolated subpopulations are. There are no available data on the number of mature individuals among different Hoary fox subpopulations. From a monitored subpopulation of Cumari, south-eastern Goiás, not all adults were able to find a mate and breed annually, and mortality of adults and dispersing young was high. Breeding males and females represented about 20-25% of monitored individuals annually (Lemos and Azevedo, pers. obs). On the other hand, genetic data obtained from Cumari and a second subpopulation from Araguari, western Minas Gerais, suggest high genetic diversity of individuals (He = 0.816, Silva 2015), despite the high degree of human disturbance in sampled areas. On a wider phylogeographic perspective, Garcez (2019) also infers that the population of Hoary Foxes is structured in only one population along Brazil, not showing signs of isolation or fragmentation. Therefore, considering 20-25% of the population is capable of reproducing, the high mortality rates of adults and dispersing young, and the low densities registered, the number of mature individuals is estimated to range between 9,840 and 19,200 mature individuals.

Considering the joint impacts of ongoing loss of habitat, road-kills, persecution, killing and transmission of diseases by domestic dogs, retaliation for the alleged predation of domestic fowl, high mortality of pups/juveniles in different populations along unprotected areas, and that this is common throughout the species distribution, it is not unreasonable to estimate that in 12 years (three generations) a decline of at least 10% of the population could occur.
The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon and patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: It inhabits low-lying marshes or inundated grasslands in the Cerrado region, where there are dense tussock-grasses (0.3-2 m in height) and usually 0.5-2 cm of standing water (D. R. Capper, J. Mazar Barnett and R. P. Clay in litt. 1999). Suitable grasslands are often located in areas of undulating terrain adjacent to gallery forest (D. R. Capper, J. Mazar Barnett and R. P. Clay in litt. 1999), but the Bolivian records were in partially flooded savanna and a belt of Cyperus giganticus fringing a lake (Brace et al. 1998).
threats: By 1993, two-thirds of the Cerrado region had been either heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), especially by mechanised agriculture, intensive cattle-ranching and afforestation (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). In Brazil, the main threat is the wholesale loss of wet campo habitats to expansion of agriculture (especially of soybean and maize monocultures) and Eucalyptus and Pinus plantations; mining and hydroelectric projects are potential threats (Castro et al. 2014). However, wet valley-bottoms are perhaps the least suitable habitat-type in the region for intensive agriculture and the species appears to tolerate some burning (D. R. Capper, J. Mazar Barnett and R. P. Clay in litt. 1999). The most significant threat is possibly the widespread use of pesticides, fertilisers and other chemicals (D. R. Capper, J. Mazar Barnett and R. P. Clay in litt. 1999).
population: A population estimate of 2,500-9,999 has been interpreted from recent records, the observation that it is relatively frequent in Distrito Federal, Brazil, and the fact that it appears to be more widely distributed that previously assumed. This would equate to 3,750-14,999 individuals, rounded here to 3,500-15,000 individuals. Verification of this estimate is desirable.

habitat: Although virtually unknown, the species has been found foraging mostly in the canopy and subcanopy (but also the understorey) of gallery and tall dry forest (where it frequently joins mixed species flocks) within the cerrado region at elevations of 700-1,000 m (Ridgely and Tudor 1994, Stotz et al. 1996), and the tropical dry forests of the São Francisco drainage (da Silva 1996).
threats: This species may be suffering from the extensive destruction of cerrado habitats for agricultural conversion (especially through overgrazing and Eucalyptus plantations), and may be affected by fire spreading from adjacent grasslands and farms. Its dry forest habitats are also under constant pressure of deforestation mainly for the charcoal industry, agriculture and Eucalyptus plantations.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but the species is described as uncommon and very local (del Hoyo et al. 2004).

habitat: It is resident in arid montane scrub (campo cerrado) and rocky outcrops in savannas and grassland (campo rupestre) at 900-1,950 m (Parker et al. 1996, Stattersfield et al. 1998) and has also been found in abandoned pastures.
threats: Much of its range was colonised when diamonds and gold were found there in the 19th century, and small operations persist. Quartz crystals and manganese are also mined. Increasing conversion of land for cattle ranching is currently the principal threat, although it persists in partially degraded areas (WWF/IUCN 1994-1997, Stattersfield et al. 1998, Vasconcelos 1999).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon'.

habitat: The species has been recorded in dry forest, riparian forest and semi-deciduous forest within the cerrado including in secondary growth and forest fragments (Lopes et al. 2008). In the dry season of 1977, it was almost always observed in pairs, 10-20 m up in the few green trees and bushes (Willis and Oniki 1991). Birds occasionally also descended to the green cotton Gossypium bushes of a plantation (Willis and Oniki 1991). In both dry and gallery forests, it appears to prefer the upper branches of taller, emergent trees, where it sallies for insect prey (Raposo et al. 2002). Nest building has been observed in October (Kirwan et al. 2004, Albano 2009), and presumed incubation in November, with a fledgling in December (Albano 2009). It occurs at low densities and can be difficult to detect, even at known sites. Its ability to disperse is unknown; given that cerrado habitats are under threat and increasingly fragmented, it is likely that many populations are increasingly isolated.
threats: Its habitat is probably the most threatened in central Brazil owing to its valuable aroeira Astronium urundeuva wood and relatively fertile soils. Charcoal-burners were fully active at the type-locality in 1986, where there was also extensive forest cutting for pasture and agricultural development. The São Francisco basin is also threatened by limestone quarrying and a large-scale irrigation project that has already resulted in the loss of large areas of forest (Raposo et al. 2002). Cattle ranching has resulted in forest clearance across large parts of the state of Minas Gerais within its range (Lopes et al. 2008). These same threats are impacting upon recently discovered locations and are exacerbated when remaining forest is highly fragmented (Lopes et al. 2008).
population: No empirical data is available, however, despite it apparent low population density and ongoing habitat degradation and fragmentation within the species's range, an extensive area of potentially suitable habitat remains that suggests the previous population estimate of 50-250 individuals needed revision. It is instead estimated to number 2,500-9,999 individuals, equating to 1,667-6,666 mature individuals, rounded here to 1,500-7,000 mature individuals.
The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common but patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996).
The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: This species inhabits campo grasslands at 1,300-2,100 m, although little is known of its ecology. It occurs locally in arid montane scrub, dry savanna and agricultural land with scattered palms and ground bromeliads. It occurs at high densities in areas of mixed habitats (Freitas and Rodrigues 2012).
threats: Much of its range was colonised by people when diamonds and gold were found in this region in the 19th century, and small operations persist. Quartz crystals and manganese are also mined. The advance of mining has been noted particularly in the rocky fields of the Espinhaço Range (both in Bahia and Minas Gerais), where most records of this species are located (L. M. Costa in litt. 2012). Increasing conversion of land for cattle ranching is presumably the principal current threat (WWF/IUCN 1997, Stattersfield et al. 1998), but deforestation may be permitting it to expand its range southward (Machado et al. 1998). The species is said to be absent in some modified areas, such as land under fire regimes for livestock grazing (Freitas and Rodrigues 2012), areas of mining activity and eucalyptus plantations (G. H. S. Freitas in litt. 2012). Its occupation of montane habitats may render it susceptible to the effects of future climate change (L. M. Costa in litt. 2012), but this requires investigation.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: Atractus spinalis parece ser endêmica de áreas de altitude da Serra do Cipó, na porção meridional da Serra do Espinhaço, uma área que se estende do centro de Minas Gerais ao norte da Bahia. Esta seção compreende áreas elevadas atingindo até 1.660 m de altitude, onde os habitats são dominados por prados rochosos (Campos Rupestres), intercaladas com pastagens e uma característica vegetação aberta com muitos elementos endêmicos. As encostas e áreas inferiores em seu lado oriental e ocidental respectivamente, contatam a Mata Atlântica e os Cerrados (Chemale Jr. et al. 2011). Todos os espécimes de Atractus spinalis foram encontrados em Campos Rupestres típicos, dentro de cupinzeiros ou sob rochas (Passos et al. 2013).
threats: O parque onde ocorre e seu entorno são  afetados por incêndios recorrentes, como o ocorrido em 2019, e a  atividade turística é intensa. Não se sabe como esses impactos afetam a  espécie.
population: Espécie descrita por Passos et al. (2013) a partir de 10 espécimes, coletados em 2011, oriundos de três subpopulações conhecidas para a Serra do Cipó, no Estado de Minas Gerais. Sua tendência populacional é desconhecida, pois não existem estudos que evidenciem variação na população.

habitat: This is a small fossorial species which probably feeds on termites and ant eggs and pupae, in common with better-known congeners. It was described from a Cerrado savanna area in São Paulo state (Vanzolini 1948).
threats: Most of the natural habitat around the known locality has been lost due mostly to the expansion of monocultures (mostly sugar cane) and urban development in a densely-populated area of Brazil. Nothing is known, however, of either this species' wider distribution or its ability to tolerate this disturbance, as some other Liotyphlops are known to tolerate habitat modification.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.

habitat: This species is a fossorial species which inhabits the savanna/shrubland Cerrado habitat of central Brazil, but there is insufficient information about its ecology and habitat.
threats: The area where the specimens of this species were collected is well-populated, and between urban areas the land has often been converted to agriculture, principally cattle ranching, causing degradation and loss of the natural Cerrado habitat. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 26% of its then-known range was still covered by native vegetation, and such dramatic losses of natural habitat may have had an adverse effect on the species (PMDBBS 2012); this figure has not been recalculated in light of new records.
population: This species is rare but apparently widespread (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

habitat: This snake occurs in the Cerrado (Martins et al. 2002, França and Araújo 2006), where it is a grassland specialist (Leão et al. 2014). It is absent from disturbed areas (Sawaya et al. 2008). This snake is terrestrial, nocturnal and diurnal (França and Araújo 2006). It is viviparous and has been found with ovarian follicles between May and September; fecundity ranges from three to 11 embryos (C. Nogueira and R. Sawaya pers. comm. 2008), and births occur between October and December (Leão et al. 2014). This small species is unlikely to have a generation length greater than three years (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). It feeds on small mammals, lizards, amphibians, birds and centipedes (Martins et al. 2002, França and Araújo 2006, Sawaya et al. 2008). It reaches 570 mm SVL (Sawaya et al. 2008).
threats: In many areas within its distribution, this species is suffering from habitat destruction, mainly the change of natural Cerrado grasslands into extensive areas of soya bean plantations and pasture. As much as 76.7% has been lost in the last 40 years, and 4.8% between 2003 and 2008 (PMDBBS 2012). This may underestimate true rates of decline, and it is thought that as many as 70-80% of known localities may have been lost since the 1970s-80s as little to no native grassland remains in these areas (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
population: Subpopulations are in decline overall in the state of São Paulo, from which most historical records have been taken (Marques et al. 1998). It is commonly found in the Estação Ecológica de Itirapina (Sawaya 2004), a relatively small protected area in this state covered mostly by grasslands. It is rare at Estação Ecológica de Santa Bárbara, another small protected area with grasslands. In the state of Minas Gerais, it is seen less frequently (A.L. Silveira pers. comm. 2012). This is a rare snake in scientific collections, and the majority of records are historical. In Brasília, fewer specimens have been collected in the last two decades (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012). Remnant patches of suitable grassland in the savannah matrix are small and heavily fragmented, and the species is considered to occur as a severely fragmented population (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

habitat: This species has been found in transition zones between typical cerrado and secondary semideciduous forest. It occurs in open areas on shrubs near pools. The egg clutch is deposited on leaves above permanent flowing water, and when hatched the tadpoles fall into streams below.
threats: Habitat loss due to mining and fires, as well as pollution from mining activities, are the major threats.
population: It is a rare species. It seems to occur at low densities at the Parque Estadual das Furnas do Bom Jesus (Araujo et al., 2007).

habitat: The species is associated to savannah-type environments.
threats: No major threats are known for this species.
population: No population status information is available.

habitat: It is found in open Cerrado savannah, with short and scattered shrubs, and breeds in small streams with the larvae developing in pools within the streams.
threats: The threats to this species are not known.
population: The population status of this species is unknown.

habitat: It occurs in pristine, shrubby campo and campo cerrado, and feeds on insects and fruit. Bamboo scrub may provide some temporary refuge after fires (Parker and Willis 1997), and it colonises recently burned areas (Lopes et al. 2010). Young birds were being fed by the parents in January and February at Serra Geral do Tocantins Ecological Station (Lopes et al. 2010). Stomach contents of these individuals contained almost equal proportions of small fruits and insects (Lopes et al. 2010).
threats: Habitat loss in the Cerrado is probably the major factor explaining its current rarity. By 1993, two-thirds of the region had been heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). There has been extensive conversion to agriculture for livestock farming, Eucalyptus plantations, soybeans and exportable crops, encouraged by government land reform in Brazil (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997). However, unlike many other cerrado birds it is not restricted to the upland cerrado of the Planalto Central, and occurs further north and in savanna enclaves in the Amazon. These Amazonian savannas, especially in Serra do Cachimbo and Amapá, are not as threatened as the southern ones, and it may also occur in other areas such as savanna enclaves in Amazonas and Rondônia, Brazil.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as rare and patchily distributed. However, in January and February 2008 it was the most common flycatcher in campo sujo and cerrado ralo at Serra Geral do Tocantins Ecological Station, central Brazil.

habitat: It inhabits seasonally wet and dry grasslands, known as "campo limpo" and "campo sujo" respectively (Parker et al. 1991, Machado et al. 1998, Silveira 1998), favouring areas of taller vegetation (30-100 cm) and, in Bolivia, especially areas of Trachypogon (Parker et al. 1991).  In southern Brazil, the species has been recorded in humid grassland dominated by Cyperaceae, as well as Poaceae, species (R. E. Fernandes Santos in litt. 2011).  Although it normally disappears from burnt sites (Cavalcanti 1988), it has been observed feeding on the ground in recently burnt areas (Lowen et al. 1996).  It is generally insectivorous, though a female has been observed feeding small fruit to two fledglings.  In Serra da Canastra it is migratory, arriving between mid-August and September and departing in December and January (Silveira 1998), but it appears to be resident at several sites in Paraguay (H. del Castillo in litt. 2007).  Breeding occurs at the start of the wet season in September and October (Parker et al. 1991, M. B. Robbins in litt. 2000).  In southern Brazil, it has been recorded nesting on the ground in a very wet area of grassland (R. E. Fernandes Santos in litt. 2011).  Despite reports, does not appear to be migratory; may be partially migratory, or exhibit seasonal changes in social behaviour, or nomadism (Marini et al. 2013).  Long-term year-round population studies are required in order to elucidate this (Marini et al. 2013).
threats: Grassland habitats throughout its range are threatened by agricultural development, livestock-farming, plantations and mining (Machado et al. 1998, R. Clay in litt. 2011).  Its dependence on tall grasslands make it especially sensitive to intensive grazing, trampling by cattle and frequent burning (Parker et al. 1991, R. Clay in litt. 2011).  Afforestation with Eucalyptus, cattle ranching and the introduction of invasive jaragua grasses are key threats to the population at Cerrado Laguna Blanca, Paraguay, where a recently instated reserve has failed to protect the species (H. del Castillo in litt. 2012).  Uncontrolled burning and the introduction of exotic grasses are major threats elsewhere in the country (H. del Castillo in litt. 2007, R. Clay in litt. 2011).  The conversion of grassland to soy plantations is an on-going threat in Brazil at least (R. E. Fernandes Santos in litt. 2011).  In Paraná, Brazil, habitat loss and modification are severe, driven largely by conversion to pine plantations (R. E. Fernandes Santos in litt. 2011).  The recently instated Reserva Natural Privada Laguna Blanca in Paraguay, within the IBA Cerrado de Laguna Blanca, failed to protect the species, which is threatened with the continuous conversion of natural grasslands into pastures with exotic African grass and Eucalyptus plantation inside the IBA.  It is predicted to lose 30–46 % of its year-round range by 2100 because of an expected range shift due to climate change (Marini et al. 2009).
population: The population is estimated to number 10,000-19,999 individuals based on an assessment of known records, descriptions of abundance and range size.  This is consistent with recorded population density estimates for congeners or close relatives with a similar body size (e.g. the lower end of such estimates is 1 / km<sup>2</sup>) and the fact that only a proportion of the estimated Extent of Occurrence is likely to be occupied.  A much higher density of 6.7 individuals / km<sup>2</sup> was found in Itirapina Ecological Station, São Paulo, Brazil (Kanegae 2012).

habitat: During a survey along the Rio Juruá of the western Amazon of Brazil, the species was found in grass patches along the river margins and agricultural areas close to rivers (Patton et al. 2000). Some female specimens examined from August to November were either pregnant or lactating; young were also observed during these months (Patton et al. 2000).
threats: There are no major threats to the species at this time.
population: This rodent is uncommon to common.

habitat: This species occurs in marshy areas and in humid grasslands, up to approximately 1,200 m (Queirolo pers. comm.). It is diurnal, and insectivorous, ecologically equivalent to O. nasutus but not as high elevation range (Vieira pers. comm.). Also, it occurs in the border between dry grasslands and wetlands (Vieira pers. comm.).
threats: The major threat is drainage of wetlands for development.
population: This species is locally abundant, most common in wet grasslands (Vieira pers. comm.).

habitat: This species occurs in gallery and semideciduous forests of the cerrado-caatinga biomes (Musser and Carleton, 2005). It is an arboreal species, found in primary and secondary forest. One specimen also found in the Atlantic Forest area in Chapada Diamantina (Bahia state) (Tribe, 2005, Geise pers. comm.).
threats: Some populations are threatened by habitat destruction and fragmentation.
population: This species is locally common.

habitat: It is crepuscular and presumably nocturnal along riverbanks in caatinga woodland, having been observed feeding high above the open river in loose flocks of up to 20 birds at dusk (J. Mazar Barnett verbally 2000). Roosting birds have been flushed from riverside bushes and the ground (Lencioni-Neto 1994, Cleere and Nurney 1998).
threats: No specific threats are known, but it must be threatened to some extent by the loss of riverine forest and scrub within its range.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but the species is described as possibly not uncommon (Cleere 1998).
The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common' (Stotz et al. (1996).

habitat: The type-specimen was taken amidst bushy vegetation in dry forest in the transitional zone between Amazonian rainforest and central Brazilian cerradão (closed-canopy cerrado). The closely related Black-and-white Tanager C. speculigera is rather nomadic, and this species could have similar tendencies. Evidence from Emas National Park suggests Cone-billed Tanager favours gallery forest and is strongly associated with water (Buzzetti in litt. 2007). Observations of the Alto Rio Juruena population strongly suggest that the species is associated with permanently or seasonally flooded areas of forest or grassland near rivers, and that it generally avoids unflooded cerrado savanna and gallery forest (Candia-Gallardo et al. 2010). The species appears to be territorial and perhaps monogamous, and it has been observed sallying for small flying insects and feeding on seeds, including those of bamboo and exotic grasses (Candia-Gallardo et al. 2010).
threats: This species is likely to have suffered from forest clearance and degradation through agricultural expansion and mechanisation in the region. The spread of soya cultivation in particular poses a serious threat outside Emas National Park (Buzzetti in litt. 2007). If the species does indeed rely on flooded riverside habitats, its population may be naturally fragmented owing to the fragmented and linear nature of suitable areas; however, in this case habitat loss would be a major threat (Candia-Gallardo et al. 2010). An impending hydroelectric project planned for Bacia do Alto Juruena and involving the construction of five hydroelectric plants will flood the Juruena river area, which appears to be the global stronghold for the species, and could extinguish more than half of the total population in a short time (MMA 2014).
population: The population is assumed to be very small as the species avoided detection for so long. The total number of mature individuals was previously estimated at 50-249 (at least 50 in Emas National Park and up to 100 in Alto Rio Juruena, Mato Grosso). The species has since been recorded at more localities and the National Red List of Brazil estimated the population to number less than 1,000 mature individuals (MMA 2014). The population is therefore placed in the band of 250-999 mature individuals, with the largest subpopulation numbering 250-500.

habitat: This species inhabits 'cerrado' and 'caatinga' habitats in lowlands (below 1,200 m). It has been observed invading recently burned areas (Ridgely and Tudor 1989, Bates et al. 1992), and may engage in local migrations or semi-nomadism in response to fire succession (Ridgely and Tudor 1989, Parker and Willis 1997).
threats: Conversion to agriculture for Eucalyptus plantations, soybeans and pastures for exportable crops (encouraged by government land reform) has had a severe impact on its cerrado habitats in Brazil (Parker and Willis 1997). Caatinga habitats are less threatened, but still suffer from agricultural expansion and grazing. At least in Brazil, it is trapped for the cage-bird trade.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon and patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996).
The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common' (Stotz et al. (1996).

habitat: The species is found in open Cerrado (savanna) vegetation on sandy soils (Recoder et al. 2011, C. Nogueira pers. obs. 2012). It has been reported from Amazonian savannas (Lema 2001), but the species has not to date been found in these habitats. Field data indicate that Apostolepis polylepis does not occur in forest (Nogueira et al. 2011, Recoder et al. 2011), but is frequently found in open areas with sandy soils.
threats: Data from 2008 indicated that at least 87% of its range was still covered by native Cerrado vegetation, within which the species is abundant. There is uncertainty as to the extent of the threats posed by  industrial agriculture; although deforestation is likely to encroach into the  plateaus of the Cerrado in the northeast states of Piauí, Maranhão, Bahia  and Tocantins (MMA 2009), this species is not found in forested areas of the savanna. Ongoing anthropogenic fire poses a  potential, but localized, threat.
population: There is no population information available.

habitat: Atractus albuquerquei has a disjunct distribution in the Amazon Forest and Cerrado. According to Carvalho and Di-Bernardo (2006), it is not common in Amazon-Cerrado ecotones. It is associated with wetlands and gallery forest. Other workers suggest that it may occur in disturbed areas with cattle farming (Bernarde and Abe 2006, Vaz-Silva et al. 2007). It feeds on worms, is fossorial and is active both by day and night (Bernarde and Abe 2006). The maximum length recorded was 492 mm (Zaher et al. 2005).
threats: Habitat loss and degradation, as a result of conversion of land to agriculture and deforestation, is occurring within the range of this species. This is however not thought to represent a significant threat.
population: No population data are available for this species, although it has been described as relatively common.

habitat: The only known record was obtained from a hydroelectric power plant in Serra da Mesa, northeast Goiás, and its ecology is essentially unknown. It is expected to be endemic to the Cerrado, and possibly to the plateaus of high Tocantins River (Nogueira et al. 2011).
threats: Although the known locality occurs in an area disturbed by the building of a hydroelectric power plant, data from 2008 indicated that at least 92% of the area within a 10 km buffer zone of the type locality was still covered by native vegetation (PMDBBS 2012). Nothing is known of any threats or of its ability to tolerate disturbance.
population: This species is known only from the holotype.

habitat: Both known localities lie in rocky savanna. The holotype was collected in savanna 100 m from a fragment of semi-deciduous forest (Curcio et al. 2012). Another individual was found inactive lying on rocks during the day, and the paratype was curled up on a small shrub at night (Curcio et al. 2012). It appears from this limited data that this may be a grassland species, rather than a forest snake as is typical for this genus, but further research is required to confirm this.
threats: No major threats have been recorded for this species. It is expected to be sensitive to an increasing frequency of fire in this region associated with agricultural activities, as this is a forest snake that will not survive in areas where forest has been burnt (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019), but the extent of this impact at present is not clear. Curcio et al. (2012) indicate that this species has been found in "relatively cold tropical habitats at high altitudes"; if it is genuinely associated with these areas there may therefore be a potential impact from climate change.
population: No information is available on population size or trends.

habitat: Apostolepis flavotorquata is fossorial and diurnal in dry forest (França and Araújo 2006). It reproduces in the dry season (Di Bernardo 2006). According to Di Bernardo (2006), most of his records were in a deserted road covered by recovering forest. Animals were found to be rare in more degraded anthropogenic habitats by França and Araújo (2006), and C. Nogueira (pers. comm. 2012) reports that it is not found in more disturbed regions of Brasília.
threats: This species is thought to be susceptible to ongoing and extensive habitat loss, and fragmentation resulting from habitat loss over previous decades (Werthein et al. 2000). Although it tolerates light disturbance, in degraded areas such as the Federal District of Brasília, the species does not persist (França and Araújo 2006). França and Araújo (2006) also suggest that this coral snake mimic may be subject to persecution, but there is no evidence from the literature that this is a significant contributor to mortality rates humans take it as a venomous snake and kill it, but literature does not associate it as a major factor in its mortality rate. Deforestation is pointed as the main threat. According to data from 2008, only 48% of its range retains native vegetation.
population: This species is relatively rare in fields and collections, although it is one of the better recorded species in a transition area (Amazônia-Cerrado, Mato Grosso state) (Di Bernardo 2006). França and Araújo (2006) suggested that may be threatened in the Federal District of Brasília, but there is no information on population trends across the range as a whole.

habitat: This snake is found in open areas of the central Cerrado (Silva and Rodrigues 2008). It feeds on small mammals, lizards, amphibians, centipedes, other snakes, and birds (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012).
threats: There are no overt threats affecting this species. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 48% of its range remained covered by native vegetation.
population: This species is evidently abundant (Silva and Rodrigues 2008).

habitat: The species is endemic to the savannas of the Cerrado (Nogueira et al. 2011), vegetation typical of the Rio das Mortes Basin.
threats: The Pimetal Barbosa indigenous community is relatively well-protected from deforestation (ISA 2012) but despite surveys the species has not been recorded from this reserve. The surrounding region was historically pastoral, but has been subject to extensive conversion for industrialized soybean agriculture and most of the remaining pasture is being converted into soybean fields (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). This form of agriculture includes regular and extensive disturbance of the soil, and so does not leave suitable habitat for this fossorial snake (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is known from a single specimen.

habitat: This snake is found in the Cerrado, including areas with "elements" of Caatinga dry forest (Dal Vechio et al. 2016). A specimen was found on interfluvial depositional sand in the Cerrado of the Estação Ecológica Serra Geral do Tocantins, state of Tocantins (Recoder et al. 2011).
threats: There are no threats known to be affecting this species. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 73% of its range was still covered by native vegetation.
population: No detailed information is available on population trends.

habitat: The species occurs in gallery forest and open forest in the Cerrado of Central Brazil, where it is generally associated with streams and rivers (Silva and Sites 1995, Franco and Ferreira 2003, França and Araújo 2006, França et al. 2008, Nogueira et al. 2010). It is nocturnal, semi-aquatic and viviparous (França and Araújo 2006, França et al. 2008). It feeds on fishes and amphibians (França and Araújo 2006, França et al. 2008).
threats: Loss of riparian habitats along the densely populated Paraná basin may pose a localized threat to this species. At least 25% of its range remained as native vegetation in 2008.
population: This species is rare in scientific collections, although recent records have been taken in the northern portion of its range (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012).

habitat: This species occurs in the Cerrado and is restricted to grasslands and disturbed areas (França and Araújo 2006, Sawaya et al. 2008, Freitas et al. 2012). It is fossorial, diurnal or nocturnal (França and Araújo 2006, Sawaya et al. 2008). This species is oviparous and has a small clutch size (5-7 eggs). It lays eggs possibly in the middle of the rainy season in December (Sawaya et al. 2008). It feeds exclusively on invertebrates: ant pupae, larvae, and sometimes adult ants, termite larvae and beetles (França and Araújo 2006, Sawaya et al. 2008). The snake reaches 340 mm snout-vent length (Sawaya et al. 2008).
threats: No major threats have been recorded for this widespread species.
population: It is relatively abundant in São Paulo (R.J. Sawaya pers. comm. 2012) and in the district of Nhecolândia, in the southern Pantanal (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2012).

habitat: This species is known only from the female holotype, collected in Cerrado vegetation on the slopes of the Serra do Espinhaço (Ferrarezzi 1993).
threats: The area surrounding the Serra do Espinhaço is subject to severe and ongoing habitat loss due to cattle farming. The impacts on this species are unclear.
population: This species is known from a single specimen collected in 1990.

habitat: This species was described from the Cerrado region (da Silva et al. 2005), but the original description provides no more specific ecological information The known locality lies within in a relatively well-preserved area of savanna or forest habitat (Passos et al. 2010). Data from 2008 indicated that at least 90% of its range was still covered by native vegetation.
threats: The type locality is thought to have been destroyed by construction of the Cana Brava hydroelectric dam (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019), but nothing is known of its broader distribution.
population: This species is known only from the holotype, collected in 2002 (da Silva et al. 2005).

habitat: The single specimen was found beneath a termite mound over rocky soil in a restricted area of the Cerrado, in a plateau of 600 m altitude in the municipality of Vilhena, state of Mato Grosso. It is likely to have a similar biology to its congeners, being fossorial and feeding on elongated prey such as amphisbaenans (Harvey 1999).
threats: Serra dos Parecis has been under pressure from deforestation (Colli et al. 2003) due to expanding cattle farming in the southern portion of the Amazon Forest and the Cerrado. The type locality is now under soybean cultivation, an intensive form of cultivation that heavily disturbs the soil and may consequently pose a particular risk to fossorial species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
population: The species is known from a single specimen so the population trend is unknown. A decrease in the quality and extent of the original habitat is nevertheless thought likely to pose a threat to this species.

habitat: This species is common in open interfluvial regions of the Cerrado, in both savanna-like habitats (typical Cerrado) and fields (campo limpo, campo sujo e campo cerrado). It is absent from gallery forest and anthropogenic areas (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012, Nogueira et al. 2011). It is a fossorial species which feeds from amphisbaenians, with an average snout-vent length of 270 mm (França and Araújo 2007, França et al. 2008).
threats: It is estimated that its range is smaller than the area of remaining forest - which exceeds 20,000 km2 within its range - because it is found only outside forest and riparian Cerrado areas. The open interfluvial areas where it occurs are preferentially targeted for habitat loss and human exploitation due to their rich soils, principally for mechanized agriculture (Nogueira et al. 2011). The recent rate of habitat loss indicates that population declines are likely to be underway.
population: Despite being relatively common in well-preserved areas of Cerrado in the Federal District of Brasília (França et al. 2008) this snake is difficult to sample and probably occurs in naturally low densities.

habitat: This snake occurs in the Cerrado and the Caatinga and is associated with sandy soil (Curcio et al. 2002, Rodrigues 2003, Nogueira et al. 2010, Pinto and Curcio 2011). Vitellogenesis occurs in January (Kawashita-Ribeiro 2007). The snake feeds on ants (larvae, pupae and adults) and termites (Cei 1993, Sawaya 2004, Kawashita-Ribeiro 2007). It reaches 248 mm in length (Curcio et al. 2002).
threats: There are no overt threats affecting this species.
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species is fossorial and occurs in the Cerrado (Passos et al. 2006). It reaches 271 mm in length (Passos et al. 2006)
threats: No major threats have been recorded for this species.
population: This fossorial species is difficult to sample and there are few records. There is no information is available on population trends.

habitat: This is a fossorial species that occurs in upland Cerrado grasslands (A.L. Silveira pers. comm. 2012) up to 1,700 m above sea level (Município de Caeté, Serra da Piedade) (Pinto and Fernandes 2012). Some specimens have been found inside caves and in holes over rocks; individuals emerge from shelter when it rains (Pinto and Fernandes 2012). The snake reaches 262 mm in length (Pinto and Fernandes 2012),
threats: There are no overt threats affecting this species. Although its range is moderately restricted, at least 68% of its range remains as native vegetation according to data from 2008 (PMDBBS 2012). This is a montane area that is difficult to convert for human use (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
population: No detailed information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species is associated with riparian situations and open areas "full of water" (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019), including palm savannas. It is not found in forest. The snake feeds on toads of the Rhinella granulosus group. One record was taken in a degraded area (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2012).
threats: There are no overt threats affecting this species.
population: This species is abundant in Nhecolândia, a region of the South Pantanal within of the municipality of Corumbá, Mato Grosso do Sul, between River Negro and River Taquari (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2012).

habitat: This species is endemic to the Cerrado. It is apparently restricted to native grassland habitats (campo sujo), but data on its ecological requirements are scarce. It is diurnal and fossorial, but active terrestrially during the rainy seasons (Sawaya et al. 2008). This species is oviparous and clutch size ranges from two to ten eggs (average five). It has a seasonal reproductive cycle, with secondary vitellogenesis between October and February (Sawaya et al. 2008). It feeds most often on lizard eggs and lizards of the family Gymnophthalmidae (R.J. Sawaya and C.A. Brasileiro, unpubl. info.). It is a small snake with an average 272 mm snout-vent length.
threats: Agricultural expansion is ongoing in central Brazil and may pose a localized threat to this wide-ranging species if it is genuinely restricted to native grasslands.
population: Sawaya et al. (2008) found this species to be moderately abundant in the Estação Ecológica de Itirapina, and did not record it from disturbed areas outside the reserve.

habitat: This species was collected from the Serra das Araras range in the Cerrado, to which it is presumed to be endemic (Nogueira et al. 2011), but there is no other information about its ecology.
threats: There is no information on any threats to this species. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 42% of the area within a 10 km radius of the known localities retained native vegetation.
population: No detailed information is available on population trends.

habitat: This is a fossorial species and may be adapted to gallery forest with sandy soil. The maximum recorded SVL was 254 mm.
threats: Rapidly expanding industrial agriculture is moving towards the plateaus of the northeastern portion of the Cerrado in the states of Piauí, Maranhão, Bahia and Tocantins (MMA 2009). This is likely to increase this species' exposure to these activities and the resulting habitat loss and fragmentation. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 90% of its range was still covered by native vegetation, and as such this species is at no immediate risk.
population: According to Curcio et al. (2011) this is a rare species.

habitat: This species is associated with gallery forest in the Cerrado (Fernandes and Puorto 1993, França and Araújo 2006, Passos 2008) and Atlantic Forest (Martins et al. 2008, Marques et al. 2009), Atractus pantostictus is cryptozoic (França and Araújo 2006) and fossorial (Rocha-Barbosa and Moraes e Silva 2009). It is as active during the day (Martins et al. 2008) as at the night (França and Araújo 2006), but is most active above ground during the rainy season in October and less between October and February (Sawaya et al. 2008). Fecundity ranges from three to four eggs (Fernandes and Puorto 1993, Cassimiro et al. 2002). It feeds on worms (França and Araújo 2006, Sawaya et al. 2008, Marques et al. 2009) and lizard scales have been recorded in the digestive tract (R. J. Sawaya and O. A. V. Marques, unpubl. data 2008). França and Araújo (2006) suggested that A. pantostictus is a habitat and dietary specialist, however, it was subsequently reported from urban areas (São Pedro and Pires 2009). Maximum recorded snout-vent length is 469 mm (Sawaya et al. 2008).
threats: High-quality cerrado grasslands are being rapidly destroyed by mechanized agriculture, intensive cattle-ranching, afforestation, invasive grasses, excessive use of pesticides and annual burning (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997). By 1993, two-thirds of the Cerrado had been heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). Nevertheless, this species is very wide-ranging, remains common where suitable habitat remains, and does not appear to be reliant on primary habitat.
population: This species is common. França and Araújo (2006) report that it is rare in the Federal District of Brasília.

habitat: This diurnal species is terrestrial and semi-aquatic, and feeds on fishes and amphibians (Cassimiro and Bertoluci 2003, Franca et al. 2008). It is found mostly in low-lying, swampy or riparian habitats, including wet grasslands (campo úmido), grasslands (campo limpo), palm grasslands (veredas), and riparian (mata ciliar) and gallery forests (floresta de galeria) (Cassimiro and Bertoluci 2003, Vaz-Silva et al. 2007, Cintra et al. 2009, Valdujo et al. 2009, C. Nogueira pers. obs.). This small snake measures an average of 305 mm snout-vent length (Franca et al. 2008),
threats: This species may be locally impacted by the loss of native vegetation due to mechanized agriculture. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 48% of its range was still covered by native vegetation.
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: The species is endemic to the Cerrado (Nogueira et al. 2011), where it is found mostly in Cerrado savanna (cerrado sensu stricto) and interfluvial grasslands, and absent from riparian or gallery forest (mata ciliar) (França et al. 2008, Valdujo et al. 2009, Nogueira et al. 2011). It is fossorial, diurnal and nocturnal (Ferrarezzi 1993, Lema 1999, Lema et al. 2005, Carvalho and Di-Bernardo 2006, França et al. 2008, Silva-Jr. et al. 2009). It feeds on amphisbaenids and other snakes (França et al. 2008). It reaches on average 950 mm in length (Ferrarezzi 1993).
threats: This species is under threat from the ongoing loss and degradation of savannas and grasslands. Although threats are widespread throughout most of the species' range (C. Noguiera pers. comm. 2019), this is a widespread snake and data from 2008 indicated that at least 550,961 km<sup>2</sup> within its range was still covered by native vegetation (PMDBBS 2012).
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species occurs in the Cerrado region (Lema et al. 2005, Nogueira et al. 2010, Recoder et al. 2011).
threats: Habitat loss due to the expansion of mechanized agriculture poses a localized threat. Data from 2008 indicated that at least 89% of its range was still covered by native vegetation.
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species occurs in Cerrado scrub grassland (campo sujo) and gallery forest, at a maximum of 1,000 m above sea level (Ferrarezzi 1993, Moura-Leite 2001, Bérnils et al. 2004, Sawaya et al. 2008, Marques et al. 2009, Vasconcelos and Santos 2009). It is fossorial, both diurnal and nocturnal, and has been found to be active during the rainy season from October to February (Sawaya et al. 2008). A gravid female 703 mm in length was found in January and laid five eggs; it had an amphisbaenian in its digestive tract (H. Ferrarezzi pers. comm. 2008). It reaches 706 mm snout-vent length (Sawaya et al. 2008).
threats: The remaining areas of Cerrado habitat in the state of São Paulo total only about 2,000 km<sup>2</sup>. They are heavily fragmented, and under threat from urban and agricultural expansion, invasive species and change in natural fire regimes.
population: This species is rare and possibly endemic to the state of São Paulo (Sawaya et al. 2008, Araújo and Almeida-Santos 2011).

habitat: This aquatic species occurs in the Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (Silva and Sites 1995, Costa et al. 2007, Scartazzoni 2009, Valdujo et al. 2009). It is oviparous (Braz et al. 2016) with a continuous reproductive cycle. Six females collected in January, May, June, September and October had vitellogenic follicles; one female collected in October had eggs in the oviduct, and neonates were recorded in March (Scartazzoni 2009). Clutch size ranges from seven to 22 eggs. It feeds on fishes and amphibians, and maximum snout-vent length recorded is 761 mm (Scartazzoni 2009).
threats: There are no known threats affecting this species. It occurs in degraded areas subject to varying types of impact.
population: No detailed information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species occurs in savannas on sandy soils in the Cerrado (Pinto and Curcio 2011, Recoder et al. 2011). It reaches 216 mm in length.
threats: No major threats have been recorded for this species. The known locality lies within the largest remaining continuous area of Cerrado.
population: There is no information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species occurs in the Cerrado of Central Brazil. The holotype and paratype were found in gallery forest, and the species may be restricted to this habitat (Arredondo and Zaher 2010). The species reaches 206 mm in length (Arredondo and Zaher 2010),
threats: This species may be under strong pressure due to deforestation, with 13.4% of gallery forest between the known localities having been lost between 2003 and 2008 (PMDBBS 2012). Mechanized agriculture, including soybean cultivation, has probably accelerated rapidly since 2008 and is likely to have resulted in more drastic declines (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is known from three specimens, from a relatively poorly-surveyed area (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

habitat: Sawaya et al. (2008) note that, while nothing is known of this small snake's natural history, in common with congeners it is probably a fossorial species that is likely to feed on elongate fossorial vertebrates. The holotype was collected from a farm close to a nature reserve, and the known localities lie within the Cerrado (Sawaya et al. 2008) The known localities are characterized by "mosaics of open Cerrado vegetation", and particularly areas with mesic climates, pronounced dry seasons and deep sandy soils known as campo sucio (known in Brazil as campo sujo - C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019) (Atkinson et al. 2018). It has been hypothesized that this species may be specialized to this microhabitat, which may explain its apparent rarity and patchy distribution as this habitat type has a "sparse distribution" (Atkinson et al. 2018).
