threats: There is ongoing and extensive habitat loss within this region due to cattle farming, agricultural, and urban expansion. Data from 2008 indicated that as little as 22.7% of the area within a 10 km2 buffer of the known localities was still covered by native vegetation (PMDBBS 2012), however, this species may be extremely localized and savanna habitat within its apparent range is restricted to small fragments (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). Flat grassland areas such as campo sucio are are often among the first to be converted to mechanized agriculture, and the small areas that remain are mostly "in poor shape" (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). Atkinson et al. (2018) state that the total area of campo siucio habitat is "tiny" (estimating that it is below 5,000 km2) This value appears to have been based on the IUCN thresholds, and the true area of campo sucio is believed to be well below this value - C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). The area around the type locality, including the Itirapina reserve, is only around 1,300 ha and this species seems to be localized even within this area; most other patches of this habitat are smaller (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). The species may consequently be at risk from the rapid conversion of these areas for agricultural use. The Rancho Laguna Blanca lies within one of the most desirable areas of Paraguay for agricultural development, and while this site was formerly a private reserve this protection expired in 2015 and Atkinson et al. (2018) reported that it was up for sale, with a high risk that it could soon be converted to ranchland.
population: This species is to date is known from four specimens collected from three localities and at intervals of nearly or more than 30 years: in 1952, 1980, and 2016 (Atkinson et al. 2018). It has never been rediscovered at either Elba farm or Rio Brilhante, despite extensive sampling using multiple approaches in remaining Cerrado in the Estação Ecológica de Itirapina, adjacent to Elba farm (Sawaya et al. 2008), and it was not recorded until 2016 at the Paraguayan locality, where reptile surveys have been ongoing since 2010 (Atkinson et al. 2018). This suggests that this is an extremely rare species or restricted to particular, discontinuous habitats (Sawaya et al. 2008), or at least that it is difficult to detect using standard survey methods (Atkinson et al. 2018). This latter is considered unlikely, as other Phalotris species were found in the reserve during these surveys (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). The population trend is unknown, but due to pressures on the Cerrado and the likelihood that this species is endemic to this habitat, it is very likely to be declining (Atkinson et al. 2018). This species appears to occur at very low densities and apparently suitable habitat is sporadically distributed (Atkinson et al. 2018), and as such it may well occur as a severely fragmented population.

habitat: This species occurs in sandy soil grasslands (campos arenosos) (Recoder et al. 2011), and in deciduous, tropical and subtropical forests in the Cerrado, 700 m above sea level of Cerrado (Campbell and Lamar 2004). It feeds on amphisbaenans and on other snakes (Roze 1996, Bocchiglieri and Reis 2008). Longevity of two years in captivity (Oliveira et al. 2005) and reaches 865 mm in length (Silva Jr. 2007).
threats: Habitat loss due to mechanized agriculture may pose a serious threat in parts of the range, however as this is a very widespread species impacts are likely to be localized.
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: This species is found in humid areas and is known to inhabit Cerrado grassland habitat (Emmons and Patton 2012). It has been recorded from well drained or rarely- and shallowly-flooded open savanna with dense bunch grass and scattered trees or shrubs (Emmons 1999). It has long claws which may serve to dig deep nesting burrows to escape threats and to dig for invertebrate prey (Emmons and Patton 2012). Stomach contents from captured specimens have included ants and insect larvae as well as some plant matter (Emmons 2015). It is not known if this species can occur in modified habitats. This species co-occurs with Kunsia tomentosa (Emmons 1999).

Small litter size and patchy occurrence imply a slow re-population potential after population decline (Emmons and Patton 2012). Agro-industry, biofuel production, and cattle raising on grasslands planted with exotic species represent the biggest threats to the habitat of this species (Emmons 2015). Failure to burn and overgrowth of the grasslands with shrubs or trees may affect population densities of this species (Emmons, L. pers. comm).
population: This species has been found to be highly variable in time and space (Emmons and Patton 2012). After long-term trapping in a standard plot, the population was noted to have undergone fluctuations which may indicate population swings leading to local extinction (Emmons 2015). The population has also been observed to be in decline in a 10-year long-term study in two localities in the lowland savannas eastern Bolivia (Emmons 2009).
The global population size has not been quantified, but the species is described as perhaps locally common, although poorly known (del Hoyo et al. 1999).

habitat: The species is found in the lower and middle growth of humid and gallery forest and woodland, favouring dense undergrowth and vine tangles.
threats: The species is presumably threatened by agricultural conversion of forested areas within the Brazilian planalto, and more information is required regarding population size and trends.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: The species is found in the undergrowth of gallery forest and patches of deciduous woodland.
threats: The species is presumably threatened by selective logging and agricultural conversion of forested areas within the Brazilian planalto, and more information is required regarding population size and trends.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'rare' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: In Brazil it favours 'campo limpo' grassland at 700-1,000 m (Parker et al. 1996, L. F. Silveira in litt. 1999, 2007), although the Paraguayan site is considerably lower (about 200 m a.s.l.), generally preferring scrubbier areas (campo sujo) than N. maculosa. It appears to prefer areas with a continuous cover of tall grasses and sedges, and has not been seen in recently burnt vegetation. Breeding is probably October-February.
threats: Suitable grasslands have been rapidly destroyed by mechanised agriculture, intensive cattle-ranching, afforestation with non-native trees such as Eucalyptus, planting of exotic grasses, excessive use of pesticides and annual burning (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997, H. del Castillo in litt. 2003, 2007). By 1993, two-thirds of the Cerrado region had been heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). In Paraguay, the Reserva Natural Privada Laguna Blanca, San Pedro is failing to protect the species since its natural grasslands are being converted to pastures with exotic grass species and Eucalyptus plantations. The population of this species has reduced to a few calling birds in a neighboring property which is now a Eucalyptus plantation (H. del Castillo in litt. 2012). Most of the known population is now in protected areas, and it is extremely rare outside them (L. F. Silveira in litt. 2012). Additionally, climate change might lead to a range contraction of over 50% by the end of the century (Marini et al. 2009).
population: The population is estimated to number 2,500-9,999 mature individuals based on an assessment of known records, descriptions of abundance and range size. This is consistent with recorded population density estimates for congeners or close relatives with a similar body size, and the fact that only a proportion of the estimated Extent of Occurrence is likely to be occupied. This estimate is equivalent to 3,750-14,999 individuals, rounded here to 3,500-15,000 individuals.

habitat: It is rare to temporarily relatively common in open campo cerrado, where there are at most a few scattered trees, mainly at 500-1,200 m (Ridgely and Tudor 1994). The species also occupies degraded habitats and agricultural land, even for nesting (Lopes and Peixoto 2018). It is often most numerous on recently burnt terrain, even where the ground is still smoking (Ridgely and Tudor 1994, de Vasconcelos et al. 2004), and has disappeared from some areas of São Paulo owing to a lack of fires in the cerrado (Willis and Oniki 1993).
threats: There has been extensive conversion of cerrado habitats to mechanised agriculture, cattle ranching and plantations of non-native tree species (da Silva 1995, Parker and Willis 1997). Two thirds of cerrado habitats had been moderately or extensively altered by 1993 (Conservation International 1999), with most destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). Suppression of fires on cerrado caused the disappearance of this species from some areas of São Paulo. Open cerrados on flat ground (such as plateau tops) are prime sites for conversion so this species may have suffered particularly badly. It does not adapt to artificial grasslands/pastures and is not found in frequently-burned savannas (L. E. Lopes in litt. 2009).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon and patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: The type specimen and a recently mist-netted bird were from cerrado woodland with open gallery forest, riparian vegetation and babaçu palm (Attalea speciosa) forest. Within this habitat, the species shows strong association with the bamboo Guadua paniculata (P. Develey in litt. 2007, Pinheiro and Dornas 2008, Leite et al. 2013), but it avoids agricultural land (Grassi Correa 2012). The species appears to specialise in feeding on ants found on bamboo canes (B. Hennessey in litt. 2010, R. T. Pinheiro in litt. 2010). All recent records relate to sightings of single individuals or pairs/family groups. Other aspects of the species's habits are unknown and it seems to occupy markedly different habitat to its sister species, Rufous-headed Woodpecker Celeus spectabilis.
threats: The main threats to the species are probably from habitat loss and degradation through fires, infrastructure development, pasture expansion and conversion to soya plantations (F. Olmos in litt. 2006, Gomes Marcelino et al. 2012). Habitat loss is particularly intense in Goiás and Maranhão, where about 70% or the native vegetation is already lost (Gomes Marcelino 2014). The species's habitat is highly fragmented, with patches of cerrado woodland mostly smaller than 5ha (Gomes Marcelino and Pinheiro 2014). In Tocantins, it has been reported that a major expansion in Eucalyptus cultivation will take place to meet demand for paper manufacturing, with more than 1 million hectares of cerrado expected to be converted to plantations (T. Dornas in litt. 2011). In addition to Eucalyptus and soybean, sugarcane is also a major crop in Tocantins (T. Dornas in litt. 2011). The species was recently rediscovered during surveys prior to the building of a new section of the Belém-Brasília highway (BR-010). The new road will facilitate access to the area and the expansion of soybean cultivation will probably follow. Preferred habitat (cerrados with bamboo patches), is frequently burned for cattle ranching; whether this practice destroys habitat or helps to maintain it remains poorly understood; however, in the short-term the extensive habitat loss, fragmentation and degradation that results is expected to have a negative effect on the species (B. Hennessey in litt. 2010). Only around 3% of this species's original habitat may remain (B. Hennessey in litt. 2010). A potential new threat is posed by the construction of dams for hydroelecticity (T. Dornas in litt. 2012).
population: A number of recent records have extended the known range of this species, which is now estimated at 6,000 mature individuals (MMA 2014). However, a recent estimate suggests that the population size might be smaller, numbering 1,500-4,000 mature individuals (R.T. Pinheiro in litt. 2016).

habitat: This species occurs in swampy gallery forest and dense streamside vegetation at 860-1100 m. It is strongly associated with permanently flooded areas dominated by Blechnum ferns and Euterpe palms (del Hoyo et al. 2003).
threats: The population trend is suspected to be declining moderately rapidly owing to habitat loss and degradation. Due to the low agricultural potential of this species's favoured habitat, it has not been greatly affected by clearance for agriculture. Nevertheless, the annual burning of adjacent grasslands must limit the availability and extent of suitable habitat (Machado et al. 1998). Wetland drainage and the sequestration of water for irrigation schemes is further reducing habitat (Machado et al. 1998). The species’s range is severely fragmented, with continuing decline in area and quality of habitat owing to pollution, water extraction, trampling by livestock and mining.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'rare' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: It was previously thought to inhabit campo cerrado grasslands and possibly open deciduous woodland but recent records suggest that this species not only persists in, but may in fact favour degraded areas, including burnt areas of campo rupestre, orchards, old pastures and abandoned mines (M. F. Vasconcelos in litt. 1999, 2007, Lopes et al. 2010). It occurs mostly at 600-1,400 m. The species may be semi-nomadic in response to fire succession and is extending its range towards degraded areas in eastern Minas Gerais (M. F. Vasconcelos in litt. 1999, 2007). The only breeding record was in September (A. Whittaker in litt. 1999).
threats: The combined effects of grazing, invasive grasses, annual burning and conversion to agriculture for Eucalyptus plantations, soybeans and pastures for exportable crops (encouraged by government land reform) (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997) had heavily or moderately altered two-thirds of the Cerrado region by 1993 (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). Mining activities are reportedly affecting habitat in the south Cadeia do Espinhaço (M. F. Vasconcelos in litt. 1999, 2007). However, recent information indicates that this species not only persists in, but may in fact favour, modified habitats such as degraded and burnt cerrado, orchards, old pastures and abandoned mines (M. F. Vasconcelos in litt. 1999, 2007). In the Atlantic Forest region of eastern Minas Gerais the species appears to be extending its range as the amount of degraded habitat increases (M. F. Vasconcelos in litt. 1999, 2007, Lopes et al. 2010). Brood-parasitism by Shiny Cowbird Molothrus bonariensis has been recorded in the Serra do Cipó and will presumably increase with conversion to pastures (Simon et al. 1999).
population: The population size is preliminarily estimated to fall into the band 10,000-19,999 individuals. This equates to 6,667-13,333 mature individuals, rounded here to 6,000-15,000 mature individuals.

habitat: There are two distinct races with differing habitat requirements: A. s. scutatus occurs in arid montane scrub and on rocky outcrops within undulating grassland at 900-2,000 m, while A.s. ilseae prefers gallery forest at 1,000-1,200 m (Pearman 1990, Sick 1993).
threats: Much of the species's range was colonised when diamonds and gold were found there in the 19th century. Up to date, small gold mining operations persist. Moreover, quartz crystals and manganese are mined. The principal threat to the species is now increasing conversion of land for cattle ranching, with its restricted range rendering it vulnerable to any form of disturbance (Vasconcelos 1999).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: In Bolivia and Brazil, it inhabits tall, sometimes seasonally wet, grasslands, to 1,200 m (Stotz et al. 1996, Brace et al. 1997). In Beni, immatures have been seen in heavily grazed grassland with numerous trees and bushes (Parker 1989), and areas of tussocky grass 50-125 cm tall with scrubby mounds (Mitchell et al. 1997). In Paraguay, it has been seen in campo sujo comprising pristine tussocky grasses, with small areas of bare ground, scattered bushes and yata'i Butia sp. palms (Lowen et al. 1996, Clay et al. 1998). There is evidence that it tolerates some grassland burning (Lowen et al. 1996, L. P. Silveira in litt. 1999), at least if the grass grows back to its full height (R. C. Brace in litt. 1999). Breeding is probably September-December (Lowen et al. 1996, Clay et al. 1998).
threats: Suitable grasslands are being rapidly destroyed by mechanised agriculture, intensive cattle-ranching, afforestation, invasive grasses, excessive use of pesticides and annual burning (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997). By 1993, two-thirds of the Cerrado region had been heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). Burning is a major problem in the Beni and fires started by ranch managers often get out of control. Although the species appears to show some tolerance to burning its preference for long grass habitats means this is presumably a significant threat (C. Hesse in litt. 2007). In Paraguay, the Laguna Blanca private nature reserve has failed to protect the species, which is threatened with the continuous conversion of natural grasslands into pastures with exotic grass species and Eucalyptus plantations. (H. del Castillo in litt. 2012).
population: The population size is preliminarily estimated to fall into the band 10,000-19,999 individuals. This equates to 6,667-13,333 mature individuals, rounded here to 6,000-15,000 mature individuals.

habitat: This species occurs in dense cerrado, and has been found in cerradão, occurring less frequently in savannas and disturbed areas (Isler and Isler 1987).
threats: Conversion to soybeans, exportable crops and Eucalyptus plantations (encouraged by government land reform in all three countries) has severely impacted cerrado habitats (Parker and Willis 1997), with grasslands in Paraguay additionally threatened by extensive cattle-ranching (Lowen et al. 1996). One study in Brazil (Duca et al. 2009) suggests that fire suppression is the most cost-effective management option for increasing populations.
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: This species occurs at 600-1,100 m in campo cerrado, and particularly campo rupestre (Parker and Rocha 1991, da Silva 1995, Parker et al. 1996).
threats: Conversion to agriculture for Eucalyptus plantations, soybeans and pasture for exportable crops (encouraged by government land reform) have severely impacted its habitat, particularly in Brazil (Parker and Willis 1997). Two thirds of cerrado habitat had been extensively or significantly modified by 1993 (Conservation International 1999), with most destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'uncommon and patchily distributed' (Stotz et al. 1996).

habitat: Vive em vegetações abertas rochosas típicas, localmente conhecidas como “campos rupestres”. É saxícola, forrageador do tipo senta-e-espera, críptica e diurna (Galdino et al. 2006), avistada nas horas mais quentes do dia sobre rochas sombreadas (Filogonio et al. 2010). Alimenta-se principalmente de cupins e formigas (Filogonio et al. 2010). Não há diferença significativa em seu horário de atividade entre as estações seca e chuvosa (Passoni et al. 2008). Sua reprodução é cíclica, ocorrendo da metade da estação seca até o final da estação úmida. Atinge comprimento máximo de 60 mm. Possui uma crista dorsal, presente em ambos os sexos (Rodrigues 1981). A atividade reprodutiva feminina foi influenciada pelo fotoperíodo e pela precipitação de longo prazo e o armazenamento de gordura variou inversamente ao período de atividade reprodutiva. A média de tamanho da ninhada foi de 2,06 (Galdino et al. 2003). Quando capturados, indivíduos podem fugir, levantar a cauda, produzir sons, descarga de conteúdo cloacal, autotomia e/ou mordidas (Galdino et al. 2006). Há registro de parasitismo por helmintos (Fontes et al. 2003).
threats: Embora os campos rupestres ainda se encontrem relativamente intactos, a agricultura e expansão urbana são possíveis ameaças a estas regiões, que ocorrem em meio a áreas já fragmentadas (IUCN 2010).
population: Espécie facilmente encontrada a mais de 1000 m de elevação dentre as áreas que ocupa (IUCN 2010).

habitat: Espécie de corpo alongado, membros reduzidos, devido ao seu hábito fossorial, vivendo entre troncos, raízes, cupinzeiros, sob pedras ou sob o folhiço de paisagens abertas das regiões montanhosas de Minas Gerais (Rodrigues et al. 2007,Rodrigues et al. 2009). Atinge até 60 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal, onde a cauda é cerca de duas vezes maior que o corpo. A ninhada é composta por apenas dois ovos (Rodrigues et al. 2007, Rodrigues et al. 2009).
threats: Apesar de não existirem dados a respeito das ameaças sobre a espécie, a destruição e a fragmentação dos ambientes de campos de altitude principalmente pelo fogo parecem ser suas maiores ameaças. A subpopulação da Serra da Piedade (Quadrilátero Ferrífero no extremo sul da Cadeia do Espinhaço) encontra-se sobre forte influência de atividades de mineração. Esta área também recebe turistas frequentemente  e tem silvicultura (A. Silveira com. pess. 2013).
population: Espécie rara, conhecida de poucos indivíduos. Aparentemente é abundante no topo da Serra da Piedade, mas é pouco conhecida no restante de sua área de ocorrência (Rodrigues et al. 2007, Rodrigues et al. 2009). Por ocorrer apenas em áreas de campo de altitude (acima de 900 m), as subpopulações encontram-se isoladas geograficamente. Todavia, as alterações sofridas no ambiente, acentuam essa fragmentação causando, possivelmente, a interrupção do fluxo gênico.

habitat: Exemplares coletados foram encontrados sob troncos ou em frestas de pedras, em regiões de Campos Rupestres sem vegetação arbustiva ou próximas a matas de galeria baixas, na região da serra do Espinhaço e adjacências. Ocorre entre 900 e 1.200 m de altitude (Martins and Molina 2008). Os indivíduos coletados durante as ações de implementação do Plano de Ação da Herpetofauna do Espinhaço,  no Parque Nacional da Serra do Cipó e Parque Estadual da Serra do Pico do Itambé, os registros da espécie foram em Campo Rupestre acima de 1.300 metros de altitude, próximos à pequenas nascentes e córregos (H. Bonfim com. pess. 2014). Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 80 mm. Há um declínio continuado da qualidade do hábitat devido a incêndios e pecuária.
threats:
O fogo, a destruição e a descaracterização e fragmentação das matas e campos rupestres representam as ameaças mais imediatas à conservação da espécie (Martins and Molina 2008).  No Parque Nacional da Serra do Cipó a espécie sofre com a constante  perda de habitat, como consequências dos incêndios, muitas vezes criminosos, que deixam o solo exposto sujeito a erosão (os campos rupestres são ambientes frágeis e de baixa resiliência). Um ano após a ocorrência do grande incêndio de 2012,  a espécie não foi mais detectada em local encontrada em 2011. No Parque Estadual da Serra do Pico do Itambé, a presença ilegal e intensa de gado na Unidade de Conservação tem ocasionado fragmentação dos campos rupestres. No Parque Estadual da Serra do Intendente, a fragmentação decorrente de incêndios criminosos e outras ações antrópicas é uma ameaça constante à preservação da espécie.

Outras ameaças como a expansão urbana e autorizações de construções em áreas de campo rupestre na Área de Proteção Ambiental do Morro da Pedreira colocam a espécie em risco. Por exemplo, a degradação ocorrida na região da Cabeça de Boi (face leste da Serra do Espinhaço na Área de Proteção Ambiental do Morro da Pedreira) através da abertura indiscriminada de estradas em área de campo rupestre e de intensa ocorrência de nascentes, para o parcelamento da área com intenção de venda de chácaras. Essa atitude deu início ao preocupante processo de erosão deste ambiente frágil e de baixa resiliência. Atividades crescentes de mineração em áreas próximas ou contínuas às áreas de ocorrência do P. cipoense também causam forte impacto ao ambiente (H. Bonfim com. pess. 2014).
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Aparentemente, trata-se de espécie rara (difícil detecção). Atualmente são conhecidos sete indivíduos encontrados na natureza (H. Bonfim com. pess. 2014).

habitat: Ocorre apenas no Cerrado, a baixas elevações na parte centro-sul da Estação Ecológica Serra Geral do Tocantins. Embora possa ocorrer em diferentes hábitats, parece ter preferência por solos arenosos, onde faixas de locomoção sub-superficiais, principalmente entre um arbusto e outro, podem ser encontradas. Acredita-se que a espécie possa ser encontrada em temperatura média da areia de 26 à 32 °C (Rodrigues et al. 2008). Foi coletada em superfície de areia na porção sul e em um platô de arenito relictual e erodido, adjacente ao “Morro do Fumo”, na porção central. Possivelmente é endêmica da porção mais ao sul do Jalapão (Rodrigues et al. 2008). Atinge entre 61 e 80 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal.  Uma larva de Scotinus sp. (Tenebrionoidea, Coleoptera) foi regurgitada pelo holótipo durante a fixação (Rodrigues et al. 2008). A ausência completa de uma evidente ornamentação do hemipênis no gênero Bachia é uma condição comum compartilhada com outras espécies (Teixeira Jr et al. 2013).
threats: Não há informações disponíveis sobre ameaças que possam levar a espécie a alguma categoria de risco de extinção. Ocorre em área de proteção ambiental, o que pode auxiliar na sua conservação, mas acredita-se que sua distribuição pode ser maior que a conhecida atualmente.
population: Não há informações sobre suas subpopulações. Diversas faixas de locomoção foram vistas por toda a estação, dificultando dizer se a espécie é rara ou não. Além disso, Rodrigues et al. (2008) decidiram não inferir sobre a densidade da espécie, visto que utilizaram armadilhas de interceptação e queda e que estas permaneceram sempre abertas mesmo durante as chuvas.

habitat: Espécie terrestre, diurna e heliotérmica, forrageia em meio a gramíneas e serapilheira esparsa (Vitt 1991, Marques et al. 2009). Tem um comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de aproximadamente 43 mm (Rodrigues 1996). Há relatos de encontro de exemplares em ninhos de formigas de Atta (Rodrigues et al. 1996). A cauda vistosa é usada em estratégias de defesa, desviando a atenção de predadores e evitando ataques letais à região do corpo e cabeça (Marques et al. 2009). Pode haver simpatria com a outra espécie do gênero, M. maximiliani.
threats: Destruição de hábitat nas regiões de ocorrência. Perda de qualidade do hábitat por isolamento, invasão de gramíneas exóticas e modificações nos regimes naturais de fogo (Marques et al. 2009).
population: Em algumas áreas a espécie pode ser abundante como em Pimenta Bueno, Rondônia e Jalapão, Tocantins (Gainsbury and Colli 2003, Vitt et al. 2007). Entretanto, no Pantanal do Mato Grosso do Sul, parece ser raro (V.L. Ferreira pers. comm. 2013).

habitat: Espécie endêmica do Cerrado, habitando tipicamente os “carrascos”, cerrados densos e florestas deciduais em planaltos da Serra Geral e adjacências, no contato entre o Cerrado e Caatinga (Nogueira and Rodrigues 2006, Recoder and Nogueria 2007). Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 90 mm.
threats: Não são conhecidas ameaças que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: A única informação disponível é que no parque Nacional Grande Sertão Veredas a espécie não é abundante (Nogueira and Rodrigues 2006).

habitat: Ocorre nos domínios do Cerrado associado a matas de galeria (Manzani and Abe 1997, Colli et al. 1998), mas no Mato Grosso ocorre exclusivamente em áreas abertas de cerrado e parque cerrado (Valadão pers. comm. 2013). É uma espécie diurna de atividade das 8h até as 15h, com uma temperatura média corporal de 33.9 (Colli et al. 1998). Alimenta-se de invertebrados principalmente de aranhas (Colli et al. 1998). Espécie de aproximadamente de 250 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Colli et al. 1998).
threats: Há perda e qualidade de hábitat pela atividade agropecuária, em especial no extremo sul de sua extensão de ocorrência. Não entanto, não há evidência de que a espécie esteja ameaçada de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Em sua localidade tipo, é abundante em hábitats abertos, nos cerrado como solo arenoso, com diminuição da sua densidade a medida que há um aumento da vegetação (Vitt et al. 2007). É terrícola e diurna. Atinge até 56 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal.  Aparentemente, as fêmeas caracterizam-se por ter diversas ninhadas durante a estação reprodutiva. O tamanho de cada ninhada parece ser fixo e de um ovo, com volume médio de 410.02 mm3. Alimenta-se de aranhas, larvas de insetos e cupins (Colli et al. 2009). Apesar de utilizar o mesmo tipo de ambiente, Ameivula mumbuca e A. jalapensis não coocorrem. Ameivula mumbuca está associada ao planalto da Serra Geral e pediplano adjacente e A. jalapensis está associada a áreas mais baixas na planície de deposição ao oeste do rio Novo e depressão do Manoel Alves (Recorder et al. 2011).
threats: Ao sul da extensão de ocorrência, a perda de hábitat tem sido intensa devido à atividade agropecuária.
population: Embora não haja informações sobre sua população, esta espécie é localmente abundante na área em que ocorre no Tocantis (Colli et al. 2009). Dados populacionais na sua área de ocorrência no extremo sul são desconhecidos.

habitat: Possui hábito diurno e é forrageadora ativa. Comum em áreas de Cerrado arenoso com pouca vegetação (Colli et al. 2003). O período de atividade da espécie ocorre entre as 08h até as 17h. A temperatura corporal média é de 36 °C (Colli et al. 2003). Tem como dieta preferencial insetos, principalmente cupins. Espécie de comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 59 mm (Colli et al. 2003). Apresenta somente um ovo por gestação (Colli et al. 2003). Sua distribuição é muito similar à de outra espécie descrita posteriormente para a mesma região (A. jalapensis), mas mesmo possuindo ecologia similar ocorrem parapatricamente.
threats: Embora grande parte da distribuição da espécie esteja em áreas protegidas como a Área de Proteção Ambiental Jalapão, Estação Ecológica Serra Geral do Tocantins e Parque Nacional da Chapada das Mesas, as áreas fora das unidade de Conservação estão sob forte ação antrópica (agricultura em larga escala), especialmente no oeste da Bahia.
population: A espécie parece ser bastante comum e abundante em áreas arenosas abertas onde ocorre (Colli et al. 2003).

habitat: Presente no Cerrado. Embora sua distribuição não seja restrita, a espécie normalmente ocorre em ambientes específicos, como carrasco e mata semidecidual (Morais et al. 2010). Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal máximo de 257 mm nos machos e 272 mm nas fêmeas. Sua coloração promove uma camuflagem sobre o substrato que ocorre (Torres-Carvajal 2005).
threats: Não há informações disponíveis sobre ameaças que possam levar a espécie a alguma categoria de risco de extinção. Todavia a porção leste da sua distribuição, está sob forte impacto da atividade agropecuária.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Única espécie de seu gênero, atinge 61 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Dixon 1974). Não há muitas informações sobre a história natural desta espécie na literatura. Encontra-se predominantemente em galerias no solo sob rochas (Rodrigues et al. 2009). Na Serra do Espinhaço, provavelmente ocorre em altitudes até 1.200 m (Rodrigues and Santos 2008). Aparentemente é rara nos ambientes onde ocorre.
threats: As maiores ameaças atuais à sua conservação são a destruição e fragmentação de hábitats (erosão, pecuária, poluição, extração ilegal de madeira, entre outras). Por se tratar de espécie aparentemente endêmica dos campos de altitude, poluentes que possam afetar a qualidade ambiental devem ser cuidadosamente monitorados na sua área de ocorrência, sejam eles de atividades industriais ou do uso indiscriminado de preventivos contra pragas agrícolas (Rodrigues 2008). Contudo, não se sabe se as ameaças estão impactando diretamente a espécie
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: It inhabits campo sujo (shrubby fields) and campo limpo (clean grass fields) with scattered shrubs (Silveira and Silveira 1998). The specimens from Paraguay and Argentina were collected in scrub grasslands (Collar and Andrew 1988, Collar et al. 1992). It has been reported taking invertebrate prey, including termites, and feeding on Graminae seeds. A pair in captivity laid three eggs (Silveira and Silveira 1998).
threats: High-quality cerrado grasslands are being rapidly destroyed by mechanised agriculture, intensive cattle-ranching, afforestation, invasive grasses, excessive use of pesticides and annual burning (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997, F. K. Ubaid in litt. 2018). By 1993, two-thirds of the cerrado had been heavily or moderately altered (Conservation International 1999), with most of the destruction having occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). Since the species can only cover c.50 m in flight (Silveira and Silveira 1998), it is presumably susceptible to fast-moving fires, and is unlikely to disperse between isolated habitat fragments. Catastrophic fires are common in protected areas such as Serra da Canastra and Emas (F. Olmos in litt. 2013). Large areas of potentially suitable habitat remain in eastern Tocantins, however fires are a serious threat here, while Eucalyptus plantations are increasing and are expected to cover more than 1 million ha in the region, converted from agriculture and natural habitat. Expansion of soy and cane sugar crops are further potential threats (T. Dornas in litt. 2013), and even protected areas are likely to be coming under increasing threat from habitat conversion (T. Dornas, A. Lees, A. de Luca and F. Olmos in litt. 2013).
population: The population is estimated to number 2,500-9,999 mature individuals based on an assessment of known records, descriptions of abundance and range size. This is consistent with recorded population density estimates for congeners or close relatives with a similar body size, and the fact that only a small proportion of the estimated Extent of Occurrence is likely to be occupied. This estimate is equivalent to 3,750-14,999 individuals, rounded here to 3,500-15,000 individuals.

habitat: It occurs in campo cerrado grasslands (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997), and was once observed in a rice-field after harvest. It is terrestrial and occurs singly or in pairs.
threats: The reasons for this species's historical rarity are unknown because, until recently, large areas of potentially suitable habitat remained. It is now severely threatened by the massive destruction of the Brazilian cerrado. The combined effects of grazing, invasive grasses, annual burning and conversion to agriculture for Eucalyptus plantations, soybeans and pastures for exportable crops, encouraged by government land reform (Stotz et al. 1996, Parker and Willis 1997), had heavily or moderately altered two-thirds of the cerrado region by 1993 (Conservation International 1999). Most of this destruction has occurred since 1950 (Cavalcanti 1999). The cerrado habitat may also be altered by climate change, which poses a further threat to the species (Şekercioğlu et al. 2012).
population: The population is estimated to number c.110-260 individuals, based on an assessment of known records, descriptions of abundance and range size. This is consistent with recorded population density estimates for congeners or close relatives with a similar body size, and the fact that only a proportion of the estimated extent of occurrence is likely to be occupied. This equates to approximately 70-180 mature individuals, placed here in the band 50-249 mature individuals.

habitat: Cipo Canastero is restricted to campo rupestre: isolated rocky outcrops with dry, bushy vegetation. It ranges from 1,100 to 2,000 m (Freitas et al. 2019a, b) and prefers steep, well vegetated slopes. The diet consists of invertebrates taken from rocks, crevices and shrubs. Pairs have been recorded holding territory in July and August, and observed with dependent young in December. Nests are situated in areas with rocky outcrops and are placed on a variety of plants, including grass, bromeliads, shrubs and trees, or directly on the ground (Costa et al. 2019).
threats:
Brood parasitism by the recently introduced Shiny Cowbird (Molothrus bonariensis) is thought to be the most serious current threat and the main cause of the species's ongoing decline (Costa 2015). A study of breeding success in A. luizae found that M. bonariensis parasitism was the biggest cause of nest failure (Costa 2011, 2015).

Fires potentially pose a serious threat to the species (L. E. Lopes in litt. 2009, Vasconceles 2009, Costa 2015). Fires are largely used to renew the grassland vegetation for use as natural pastures  and may also be caused by conflict between people and protected areas, as well as by lightning (Ribeiro and Figueira 2011). Although the campos rupestres is adapted to fire, anthropogenic changes in the fire regime increase the frequency and intensity of fires, reducing the ability of the ecosytem to recover (Figueira et al. 2016). Fires are more frequent in the dry season, which coincides with the Cipo Canastero's breeding season (Costa 2015). An analysis of fire history in the Serrado Cipo National Park and Morroda Pedreira Environment Protection Area found that 75% of the study area had been burned at least once between 1984 and 2014, and 48% of the area was burned every 1-2 years (Alvarado et al. 2017). In some years, the total burned area was more than 300 km2 (Alvarado et al. 2017). However, fires in the Serrado Cipo National Park do not usually burn more than a hectare (Figueira et al. 2016).

Small numbers of cattle are scattered along the Espinhaço mountains, but they are not present on the steep slopes or rocky areas (M. F. de Vasconcelos in litt. 2009). Incursion of invasive grasses may be reducing the quality of the species's habitat (Freitas et al. 2019b). The construction of a new road destroyed some habitat at the type locality. Development for tourism and infrastructure continues to pose a threat, as does mineral extraction within the Espinhaço Range. More than 40% of the species's habitat is currently either directly or indirectly affected by mining (Pena et al. 2017).

Climate change is likely to pose a significant threat in future decades. A model of the impact of climate on the potential range of rupestrian grassland in the Espinhaço Range predicted that around half would be lost by 2080 (Bitencourt et al. 2016). Other models indicated that rupestrian grasslands might lose up to 95% of their current suitable area by the end of the century (Wilson Fernandes et al. 2014).
population:
When discovered, the species was described as 'not uncommon in a small area at Serra do Cipo, Minas Gerais' (Pearman 1990). The species seems to be more abundant in the northern part of its range, especially in the Diamantina plateau and central Espinhaço in central-northern Minas Gerais state (M. F. de Vasconcelos in litt. 2009).

The species has a strongly male-biased sex ratio (Freitas 2011, Costa 2015), with an adult population composed of c.70% males (Costa 2015, Freitas et al.2019). As a result, a low proportion of the adult population (47%) are in breeding pairs (Costa 2015).

Surveys in 2009-2010 in Serra do Cipó found a mean population density of 29 individuals per km2 in campo rupestre habitat, and 13 individuals, and five breeding pairs, per km2 across the study area (Freitas 2011). Another analysis of surveys at Serra do Cipó provided mean population densities of 35.2 adult individuals per km2 in campo rupestre habitat, and 13.6 adults per km2 across the study area (Freitas et al. 2019a). Considering paired individuals only, this study found an average of 22.9 per km2 in campo rupestre habitat, and 8.7 per km2 across the study area (Freitas et al. 2019a). Surveys from 2009-2015 in Serra do Cipó found an average density of 17 adult individuals per km2 of rocky outcrops, and 8 adults per km2 of study area, with a lower density of paired individuals (7 and 3 respectively) due to the sex ratio bias (Costa 2015). Based on the area of habitat within the species's range, the species' global population size was projected to be around 21,800 (7,400 - 47,600) paired individuals (Costa 2015).

Updated estimates of the area of suitable habitat were derived from a species distribution model by Freitas et al. (2019b). By multiplying average numbers of paired individuals found by Costa (2015) by the new estimated area of habitat, the population size was estimated at 12,792 (3,655-29,238; L. M. Costa and G. H. S. Freitas in litt. 2020). By removing some area of the modelled range polygons without nearby records, a more conservative version of the modelled range was produced, which represented 83% of the original area. Multiplying the above population estimated by 83% produced a more conservative population estimate of 10,617 (3,034-24,268).

Based on the estimates described, the population size is here placed in the band 3,000 - 48,000 mature individuals, with a best estimate of 10,600.

The species's range is divided into three areas separated by some distance and there are at least three subpopulations. L. M. Costa (2015) estimated 700 mature individuals in the northern part of the range, 1,900 in the central part and 19,800 in the southern part. However, it is likely that there are further subpopulation divisions within these blocks, particularly the southern block, due to narrower gaps of around 10 km between areas of suitable elevation. The species is thought to have a low dispersal distance (Costa 2015). A study of the species's habitat and elevational range identified nine 'sky islands' within the species's range, which may represent separate subpopulations (Freitas et al. 2019b). By multiplying the area of each ‘sky island’ by the proportion of each sky island that falls within the species distribution model (from Table 1 in Freitas et al. 2019b) to find the area of the distribution model in each, then dividing the population estimate between the sky islands according to their relative area of species distribution model, the largest sky island (Cipó North) is estimated to hold 974-15,287 mature individuals (here rounded to 900-16,000), with a best estimate of 3,404 (here rounded to 3,000).

habitat: In common with other amphisbaenians, this species is fossorial. The single known specimen was collected buried c. 60 cm deep below the surface, on a sparse savanna area on deep, well drained sandy soils. Amphisbaena acrobeles was described from an injured individua: the length from its head to the injured part was 174 mm (Ribeiro et al. 2009), and ants and termites were found in the stomach of the holotype (Ribeiro et al. 2009).
threats: There are no overt threats affecting this species. Its type locality is in a well preserved ecological station that is part of an Environmental Protected Area, and is covered by 95% native vegetation (Ibama 2014).
population: Amphisbaena acrobeles is known from only its holotype (Ribeiro et al. 2009), and no information is available on population trends.

habitat: The holotype is 139 mm SVL and was collected in a cattle farm in Cerrado vegetation (Strüssmann et al. 2009).
threats: At the time of collection of its holotype, its type locality was a cattle farm. The surroundings have been converted for the reservoir of the Manso Hydroelectric Dam, and land in this area is subject to land speculation with the prospect of attendant land conversion.
population: Population trends are unknown.

habitat: In Vilhena this lizard occurs in sandy, open, scrubby grassland in Cerrado enclaves (Colli et al. 2003a). It is diurnal (9 am to 1 pm) and reaches a maximum temperature of 38.2°C (Colli et al. 2003a). The species is an active forager and feeds mainly on arthropods, termites, ants, spiders and beetles (Colli et al. 2003a). Females lay one or two eggs (Colli et al. 2003a).
threats: This species is under strong pressure due to anthropogenic activity. Its type locality in Vilhena retains less than 10% of its native vegetation remaining, and the Cerrado where it occurs is under pressure from the construction of the Ferronorte railway  and the Rio Madeira waterway (Colli et al. 2003a). Its native Cerrado, especially the in the Parecis plateau (in Rondônia and adjacent west-central Mato Grosso), is being converted for crops, mainly soy plantations. Another threat is the construction of hydroelectric dams; specimens from Sapezal were rescued from one of the dams.
population: This is one of the most abundant lizards in the Cerrado enclaves of Vilhena, state of Rondônia (Colli et al. 2003a).

habitat: This lizard has been found in savanna. It lives under the leaf litter, in the shade of large trees such as the Pequi (Caryocar brasiliense). One individual was found under a dead tree trunk and two in leaf litter under bushes (Teixeira et al. 2013).
threats: The Cerrado is suffering from intensive deforestation due to cattle farming. Little is, however, known about the biology of this species, and although it is known from a small number of records these encompass a wide area.
population: This species is known from only a few records and there is insufficient information on population trends.

habitat: This species is known from ecotones between seasonal semi-deciduous forest and the Cerrado. The holotype was found on a broken branch on the ground, in a Cerrado fragment between the Rio Paraguai and the Serra do Facão, in the municipality of Cáceres, state of Mato Grosso (Castrillon and Strussmann 1998). A centipede and remains of adult insects were found in the stomach (Castrillon and Strussmann 1998). All members of this genus are fossorial.
threats: This species is known only from its type locality, an isolated patch of Cerrado in the state of Mato Grosso. The development of an industrial zone, the Zona de Processamento and Exportação de Cáceres (Castrillon and Strussmann 1998), has caused considerable deforestation and loss of natural habitat, but nothing is known of its broader distribution or its tolerance of habitat modification.
population: Only three specimens have been recorded, and there is consequently no data on the population status of this species.

habitat: The species was found on the sandy banks of the Rio Tocantins, in a Cerrado fragment. Average annual precipitation there is 1,800 mm. Historically this area contained a seasonal semi-deciduous forest enclave surrounded by Cerrado, but a large portion of this forest has been destroyed and what remains is remnant tall trees, with thick leaf litter on sandy soil (Rodrigues et al. 2007, 2008).
threats: A large portion of the once extensive, seasonal semi-deciduous forest has been destroyed (Rodrigues et al. 2007), much of it due to flooding resulting from the construction of the Luis Eduardo Magalhães hydroelectric dam.
population: The only data on the population status of this species is from a single survey of 880 pitfall bucket/days at the type locality in 2001. Only the five specimens in the type series were found.

habitat: This lizard is known from sandy Cerrado enclaves of the Cerrado from 300 to 800 m above sea level. One individual was recorded feeding on larvae (Gainsbury and Colli 2003). Due to the difficulties in collecting semi-fossorial species, there is little information on its natural history, ecology and distribution (Freitas et al. 2011). The known specimens ranges between 49.2 and 88.6 mm SVL, and total length from 161.4 to 168.9 mm (Freitas et al. 2011).
threats: Conversion of Cerrado habitats for agriculture, which is especially pronounced within this species' range in the Chapada dos Parecis plateau, is the main threat. Less than 10% of native Cerrado remains in the municipality of Vilhena, and elsewhere it is under threat due to the Ferronorte railway and the Rio Madeira waterway (Colli et al. 2003). Hydroelectric dams present another threat. New species of the Bachia bresslaui group have been described in areas that have been inundated following the construction of dams.
population: This species is known from seven records across two localities. It is semi-fossorial and difficult find (Freitas et al. 2011).

habitat: This species occurs in the Cerrado and Campo Cerrado (Nogueia 2001). Recent specimens were collected in an ecotone between Cerrado and Matto Grosso Tropical Dry Forest (Costa et al. 2019). There is very little information on the specific natural history of this species, but amphisbaenids are fossorial. The broad region is savannah with annual mean temperatures in excess of 18 °C (Alvares et al. 2013), on varied soil types but most records are from areas where the main soil type is ferrasol (Costa et al. 2019).
threats: The type locality is subject to intense agriculture and cattle ranching. As its soil is being degraded as a result of this activity, the population of this fossorial species may be in decline, but it is unknown whether this represents a widespread threat. Although there is a loss of native vegetation in the species distribution area, due to the practice of mechanized agriculture, there is no evidence that this activity puts the species at risk of extinction.
population: No information is available the abundance of this species or on population trends, although it is possible that the population is at least locally impacted by agriculture.

habitat: This species occurs in the Cerrado in the state of Maranhão, extreme west of Northeast Brazil (Gomes and Maciel 2012).
threats: Its habitat quality is declining due to cattle farming and agriculture.
population: No information is available on population trends.

habitat: The specimen collected on the northern margin of the Rio Santa Luzia was in an area called Tombador de Areia. This is the largest and tallest dune area at of white sand at 50 m above sea level, covered by open vegetation and sparse bushes. It used to be found close to the broad gallery forest of the alluvial plain of the Rio Santa Luzia, and now remains only along the margin of the reservoir following flooding of the lower valley. Tracks used to be found frequently.
threats: A large portion of the seasonal semi-deciduous forest surrounded by the dominant Cerrado vegetation has been deforested (Rodrigues et al. 2007). According to G. Costa (pers. comm. 2014) no individuals were found after the flooding of the hydroelectric reservoir and the dunes where the species used to occur. The dam was completed approximately 10 years prior to this assessment.
population: This species appears to be hard to find, as it is rarely recorded but its trails are often observed. Only two specimens were found in a survey of 880 pitfall buckets/days. Following the deforestation and flooding of the reservoir of the Luís Eduardo Magalhães hydroelectric dam, more than 80% of its population is thought to have been lost.

habitat: All specimens were collected from Cerrado in the area near Luis Eduardo Magalhães hydroelectric dam, in the state of Tocantins (Castro-Mello 2003).
threats: The Cerrado where this species occurs was inundated by the reservoir of the Luiz Eduardo Magalhães hydroelectric dam, which undoubtedly resulted in the loss of subpopulations in inundated areas, although the known records of this species (taken in 2003) were taken shortly after construction of this dam was completed. The species is probably in decline due to land purchases for housing estates, human occupation, and changes in river flow. Adjacent areas have been well surveyed but no other records have been taken.
population: No information is available on population trends. Surveys since its original description have failed to record it, suggesting that it is rare.

habitat: This species was found in dry forest in an ecotone between the Cerrado and the Atlantic Forest. It reaches 185 mm SVL (Vanzolini 1994).
threats: The species is under threat from cattle farming, industrial scale monocultures (mostly sugarcane) and urban expansion, causing decline in habitat quality including degradation of the soil. In 2008 only 26% of the surrounding area (within a 10 km radius buffer zone) remained as native vegetation.
population: This species is known from a single specimen and has not been recorded for more than 25 years, although the type locality lies within a relatively well-sampled area close to both urban centres and research institutions (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

habitat: The Saffron-billed Sparrow typically occurs in tropical deciduous woodland, from sea-level up to 1400 m a.s.l., where although a forest species, it is typically found near edges, trails, clearings or tree-fall gaps (Jaramillo 2019). It further occurs alongside the edges of tropical lowland evergreen forests and galley forests along waterways where fire and other environmental conditions prevent the spread of vegetation away from the river banks (Gunningham and Slager 2015, Jaramillo 2019). The species also occurs in second-growth forests as well as more mature, primary forest (Gunningham and Slager 2015).
threats: There is an absence of evidence of any substantial threats to the Saffron-billed Sparrow. Evidence suggests that the Saffron-billed Sparrow flourishes in patchy and/or disturbed and logged forest as result of its preference for edge habitats and small clearings (Miranda et al. 2010, Gunningham and Slager 2015).
population: The global population size has not been quantified, but this species is described as 'fairly common' relative to other neotropical birds (Gunningham and Slager 2015).

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possuem corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. E a cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). Amphisbaena absaberi pode chegar à 275 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Strussmann and Carvalho 2001). Supõe-se que a espécie tenha ciclo reprodutivo sazonal, ocorrendo na estação chuvosa (Strussmann and Carvalho 2001). Sua dieta inclui formigas e besouros como itens alimentares (Strussmann and Carvalho 2001). A espécie foi encontrada no bioma Cerrado, associado à vegetação denominada cerradão (Strussmann and Carvalho 2001).
threats: Cáceres é um município que vem expandindo seu parque industrial e consequentemente a área urbana. Todavia, não se sabe o quanto esse crescimento impacta a espécie.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e habitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). Amphisbaena anaemariae pode atingir até 144 mm de comprimento rostro-cloacal (Vanzolini 1997). Parece habitar florestas secas e pode ser encontrado em ambientes alterados (Santos et al. 2014).
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa, na área de distribuição da espécie, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie.

habitat: Os anfisbenídeos são répteis fossoriais, principal característica do grupo, o que molda a sua morfologia, ecologia e hábitat. Devido a isto, é um dos grupos de Squamata menos conhecidos. Possui corpo cilíndrico, robusto, uniforme, desprovido de patas. Sua cauda é forte e curta, com o mesmo formato que a cabeça (Cunha 1961). A espécie pode atingir até 264 mm de comprimento total (Vanzolini 1997).
threats: Na área de distribuição há desmatamento, agricultura mecanizada e implantação de empreendimentos imobiliários e hidrelétricos.
population: Trata-se de uma espécie de difícil encontro e de diagnose relativamente fácil, não há informações disponíveis sobre abundância para esta espécie. Faltam informações sobre tamanho/estrutura, tendências e distribuição da população.

habitat: É saxícola, ocorrendo em afloramentos rochosos, campo sujo e cerrado típico, entre árvores, arbustos e rochas expostas (Van Sluys 1992, Recoder and Nogueria 2007). Possui atividade unimodal, com pico entre as 10 e 15 horas (Faria and Araújo 2004). Recentemente foi descrito um comportamento de se enterrar (Da Silva et al. 2012) e fingir de morto (De Carvalho et al. 2011) como mecanismos de defesa para a espécie. Foi relatado também disputa de machos pela fêmea e dados de comportamento de cópula e corte. Ambos os sexos são territorialistas e exibem comportamentos agressivos (Vaz et al. 2008). Há diversos estudos sobre infecções de parasitas, entre eles (Ávila et al. 2011) destaca um exemplar de Aparecida do Rio Doce infectado por 19 nemátodes. Seu ciclo reprodutivo é sazonal, onde fêmeas reprodutivas são encontradas de setembro à março e machos reprodutivos ao longo do ano, exceto de fevereiro a abril, quando ocorre uma redução no volume médio dos túbulos seminíferos e uma menor quantidade de espermatozóides no testículo e no epidídimo (Van Sluys 1993b, Ferreira et al. 2009). Assim, a ovoposição ocorre na época chuvosa e o recrutamento entre Janeiro e Abril (Van Sluys 2000). Sua dieta é composta principalmente de formigas e cupins (Faria and Araújo 2004). Hemípteros, coleópteros, larvas de lepidópteros e aranhas também foram comidos comumente, com registros vegetais na (Van Sluys 1993a). Parece que a territorialidade interespecífica é o mecanismo de coexistência desta espécie com T. torquatus (Faria and Araújo 2004). Realiza um maior número de saltos e consegue reduzir a velocidade absoluta de sprint, diferentemente de sua espécie irmã, T. psamonastes (Kohlsdorf et al. 2004). Atinge comprimento rostro-cloacal médio de 71.8 mm.
threats: Embora haja perda de vegetação nativa na área de distribuição da espécie, não há ameaças evidentes que possam levá-la algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Embora não haja informações sobre suas populações, esta espécie parace ser bastante comum.

habitat: Tropidurus montanus é um lagarto diurno. Saxícola, tem preferência por campos rupestres, áreas de mais de 900 m de elevação. Ocorre na Serra do Espinhaço e em outras formações montanhosas disjuntas (Carvalho 2013). Em estudo sobre sua estratégia de defesa, foi verificado que a primeira reação é a imobilidade e quando perturbada, a fuga (Machado et al. 2007). Já foi observado um comportamento de mergulho em um córrego após perseguição (Cassimiro et al. 2009). Sua atividade está ligada às temperaturas do ambiente, encontrada exposta à luz solar sobre rochas expostas, tanto na época de seca quanto na época de chuvas. Na estação seca encontra-se ativa durante 9 horas (entre 9 e 17 horas) e na estação chuvosa durante 12 horas (entre as 7 e 18 horas) (Filogonio et al. 2010).
threats: Não são conhecidas ameaças que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Embora não haja informações sobre suas subpopulações e  a não ser que é restrita a áreas de altas altitudes, parece ser abundante nas áreas em que ocorre.

habitat: O microhábitat preferencial utilizado pela espécie foi a superfície das rochas (hábito saxícola). A espécie mostrou padrão de atividade unimodal, frequentemente observados parados e expostos ao sol entre 9:00 e 10:59 horas (Meira et al. 2007).  A dieta de T. oreadicus é generalista. Em uma das suas localidades de ocorrência, a Serra dos Carajás, apresentou 21 categorias de itens alimentares, consistidos de artrópodes (principalmente formigas, larvas de insetos e besouros), parte de um vertebrado e de material vegetal, como flores, principalmente nos machos (Rocha and Siqueira 2008). Além disso, apresentaram mudanças ontogenéticas e diferenças intersexuais na dieta, provavelmente associadas à alocação diferenciada dos recursos para o crescimento ou produção dos gametas (Meira et al. 2007). A reprodução é provavelmente sazonal, ocorrendo principalmente nos meses de maior pluviosidade. São animais sexualmente dimórficos, com os machos adultos maiores que as fêmeas (Meira et al. 2007). Foi observado um comportamento de canibalismo na espécie e a predação de outra espécie de lagarto, Cercosaura schreibersii (Albuquerque 2010). Foi também registrado um exemplar da espécie predado pela aranha Lycosa erytrognata (Lycosidae, Aranae) (Bocchiglieri and Mendonca 2010).
threats: Não são conhecidas ameaças que possam levar a espécie a algum grau de risco de extinção.
population: Embora não haja informações sobre suas populações, esta espécie parace ser bastante comum.

habitat: This snake is an inhabitant of open vegetation, disturbed areas (including urban areas - Lema 2001, Ferrarezi et al. 2005) and forest edges in the Cerrado and marginal areas of the Atlantic Forest, Caatinga and Pantanal (Nogueira et al. 2019). The snakes of this genus are fossorial and diurnal (Marques et al. 2015). They usually feed on amphisbaenians, small terrestrial or fossorial snakes (Marques et al. 2015), possibly including blind snakes. It is an egg-laying species (Lema 2001).
threats: There are no widespread threats to this snake.
population: There is no information on the population status of this species.

habitat: The species breeds during the austral summer/wet season in seasonally flooded grassland with scattered bushes and trees, which are frequently clumped on decomposing termite mounds. The diet consists primarily of grass seeds. It may be nomadic and/or migratory since it seems to occur in some areas only in the dry season (Willis and Oniki 1990; S. Davis in litt. 1995, 1999). Birds recorded near Concepción, Santa Cruz, were thought to be on passage (Davis 1993).
threats: The effects of extensive and continuing conversion of grassland habitats to agriculture are intensified by its possibly nomadic and/or migratory behaviour. Satellite images reveal that large areas in west Mato Grosso have been converted to agriculture (Killeen and Schulenberg 1998). Breeding sites are presumably affected by cattle-grazing and trampling (S. Davis in litt. 1995, 1999). Trapping for the cagebird trade may be an additional threat (ICMBio 2018).
population:
The species is rare and local. The majority of the population is found breeding in Flor de Oro in Noel Kempff Mercado National Park, Santa Cruz, Bolivia. Breeding and several flocks of up to 60-70 birds have been recorded in October-December and several hundred have been estimated in late May, but very few individuals have been found in July-October (S. Davis in litt. 1995, 1999). A population of around six pairs rearing 6-10 juveniles per year occurs near San Ignacio de Velasco, Santa Cruz, in the wet season (S. Davis in litt. 1995, 1999). East of Vila Bela da Santíssima Trindade, Mato Grosso, 55 presumably breeding birds were counted in January 1988 (Willis and Oniki 1990), at least 100 non-breeding condition birds were present in July 1997 (L. F. Silveira in litt. 1999), 100-200 in August 2007, and 100 in June 2008 (Kirwan and Areta 2009).
A local density of 2 individuals/km2 was estimated at Los Fierros, Noel Kempff Mercado, Bolivia, from numbers of adult males seen in August-September (Pearce-Higgins 1996). An extrapolation of this density to the occupied area in Brazil led to a national population estimate of 5,480 mature individuals (ICMBio 2018). Brazil comprises roughly half of the global range. The majority of the population in Brazil appears to be resident birds and non-breeding visitors from Bolivia; consequently, to account for migratory individuals, the global population is assessed as substantially less than double the population in Brazil. It is here tentatively placed in the band 2,500-9,999 mature individuals (see also Willis and Oniki 1990; S. Davis in litt. 1995, 1999; Pearce-Higgins 1996; L. F. Silveira in litt. 1999).The subpopulation structure has not been investigated, but due to its migratory nature the species is tentatively assessed as forming one subpopulation (see also ICMBio 2018).

habitat: This species occurs in Cerrado savanna where it is a specialist of open habitats (e.g. rocky fields), where males calls on riparian shrubs next to mountain springs, and small streams and ponds (Bradão et al. 2009; R. Magalhães pers. comm. 2021). Its reproductive period occurs during the dry season of the Cerrado biome (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2021).
threats:
The species' habitat, grassland formations in the Cerrado (e.g. rocky field and open cerrados), has been drastically reduced and fragmented over the past 35 years. The major threats to this species are habitat loss and degradation, caused mainly by the conversion of natural areas to agricultural land and pasture, the use of fire for agricultural management, and disturbance from tourism (even within protected areas), and pollution of breeding habitats (Brandão et al. 2009, Haddad et al. 2016).

In some areas there are mining activities and soy plantations. The Mineiros region is very fragmented. One of the known localities, in the region of the mouth of Corrego Palmeira, a tributary on the right bank of the Manso River, was flooded by the reservoir of the Manso Hydroelectric Power Plant, causing its local extinction (C. Strussmann pers. comm. 2021). The annual fires in Chapadas dos Guimarães due to candles lit periodically during religious services, in addition to agricultural practices can impact the breeding success when carried out during the dry season (R. Magalhães pers. comm. 2021).
population:
It is an uncommon species, not abundant, and with a disjunct population. The habitat throughout its geographical distribution has been fragmented. Connection between subpopulations has been lost due to the severe fragmentation of natural habitats. Each subpopulation has a specific genetic variant, with very low genetic diversity, with no intrapopulation diversity (probably there is little or no gene flow between them) (R. Magalhães pers. comm. 2021). The population trend is inferred to be decreasing due to ongoing habitat loss and it is thought to be severely fragmented.

In Parque Nacional Chapada dos Guimarães, it occurs at very low densities in just a few creeks and streams (Brandão et al. 2009, Haddad et al. 2016). The species appears to be well protected in the Área de Proteção Ambiental Mata Fria (APA) and in the Área de Proteção Ambiental of Chapada dos Guimarães, with some subpopulations occurring at various points within the Parque Nacional Chapada dos Guimarães. A local extinction due to the Manso Hydroelectric Plant has been confirmed by a lack of records at sites where the species had been recorded prior the creation of the reservoir (C. Strüssmann pers. comm. 2021).

habitat: This species is found in dense vine tangles in riparian thickets and forest undergrowth near water (frequently in seasonally flooded areas and oxbow lakes). It is dependent on habitats generated by the cycle of flooding and ebbing of the rivers (D. Lima in litt. 2020). Feeds individually, in pairs, or in small family groups on a variety of invertebrate prey (Olmos et al. 2006). Forages in thick vegetation but occasionally pursues flushed prey in flight (del Hoyo et al. 2003). Breeds from May to July (Crozariol 2011).
threats:
Its specialised habitat requirements make the species susceptible to changes in hydrological management. The greatest threat to the species is the development of hydroelectrocity projects (HPP), which are likely to flood large parts of the species's habitat (Brasil Choueri et al. 2017, Dornas and Pinheira 2018, D. Lima in litt. 2020). The Estreito Hydro-Power Complex was recently constructed in the Tocantins-Araguaia river basin and within the species's range (T. Dornas in litt. 2020), going into operation in 2012. The reservoir of this project reaches between Estreito (Maranhão) and Palmeirante (Tocantins; Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). Two hydroelectrical plants projects are currently in progress within the species's range: HPP Marabá (Pará) and HPP Santa Isabel (Tocantins). HPP Marabá is projected to produce a reservoir that will reach the dam of HPP Santa Isabel on the Araguai River, and HPP Serra Quebrada in Itaguatins (PAC 2018). HPP Santa Isabel is planned for the region of the Rapids of Santa Isabel, and the reservoir is projected to reach Araguanã (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). There are plans to construct two further hydroelectrical plants (HPP) within the species's range by 2025: HPP Araguanã and HPP Serra Quebrada, both in Tocantins, but the plans are currently on hold and they are not expected to be constructed within the next 5-10 years (T. Dornas in litt. 2020). HPP Araguanã is projected to create a reservoir that will come close to Araguacema, and HPP Serra Quebrada will dam  the Tocantins river, with a reservoir reaching HPP Estreito (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). If all the planned hydroelectricity projects are executed, they may alter almost 500 km of river for each of the two major rivers affected (D. Lima in litt. 2020).

Habitat loss is ongoing within the species's range, especially due to clearance for agriculture. Rates of deforestation in Brazil have increased from 2018-2019 (INPE 2019).

A climate vulnerability analysis projected that climatic conditions across the species's entire range will exceed those currently experienced by the species by 2015 (Borges et al. 2019).
population:
Although restricted in range and extent of habitat, it is common where it occurs. A study of ten territories at RPPN Canguçu in Tocantins found an average territory density of 0.31 per ha (31 per km2), ranging from 0.14 to 0.64 ha (Crozariol 2011). Based on these densities, a population of 220,000 pairs was estimated for Cantão State Park (Crozariol 2011). Studies at the Murici and Preto rivers, tributaries of the Araguaia, in the north of Tocantins, detected at least 22 individuals in a 1 km transect in floodplain vegetation (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018).

Based on knowledge of the species's distribution and population densities, the population size has been estimated at 15,000 - 20,000 mature individuals (T. Dornas in litt. 2020). Based on the recorded population densities, the area of tree cover with 50% canopy cover within within the species's mapped range (estimated at 46,600 km2; Global Forest Watch 2020), and assuming 10-25% of the forest is occupied, the population is estimated at 195,720-489,300 individuals, roughly equating to 130,480 - 326,200 mature individuals. Based on these estimates, the population size is here placed in the band 15,000 - 350,000 mature individuals.

There are no large gaps between areas with records and the species is considered to have a relatively high dispersal ability (Borges et al. 2019), so it is assumed to have one subpopulation.

habitat: This species is endemic to the Cerrado biome. It was found in dry, open, shrubby savannah on low vegetation surrounding temporary and permanent ponds, in which it presumably breeds by larval development.
threats: The threats to the species are unclear and its tolerance of disturbance is unknown. However, based on the habitat in which it was found and the human activities surrounding the type locality, it is probably threatened by the conversion and degradation of its habitat. These are driven by urban expansion, agricultural development (for both crops and livestock), and the use of fire to create and maintain agricultural areas.
population: This species is considered rare and difficult to find. The population status is unknown.

habitat: This species is endemic to the Cerrado biome. On the Serra do Cipó in Minas Gerais, the species occurs in "campos rupestre" rocky, humid montane savanna. Other records are from the submontane and montane grassland habitats of the Cerrado grassland-Araucaria Moist Forest matrix, which occurs inland from the Atlantic Forest biome (Baldo et al. 2019). It is an explosive breeder with activity restricted to a few days at the beginning of the rainy season (hence making it potentially difficult to locate at other times). It breeds by larval development in swamps or temporary puddles. It does not tolerate the conversion of its savannah and grassland habitat to urban areas and crop cultivation. However, livestock grazing does not appear to be a threat at present as the species persists in pastures (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
threats:
The growing population of Brazil is causing the expansion of urban areas and associated increases in crop cultivation in the open areas utilized by the species. However, at present, the scope and severity of habitat conversion and degradation caused by these changes appear to be a affecting a minority of the population and are therefore only localised threats that are not causing major declines. However, in the southern part of the distribution - in Santa Catarina and Parana - the conversion of lower elevation grasslands to crops cultivation and the general intensification of agriculture, as well as the expansion of silviculture in the higher elevations grasslands, are expected to continue increasing. While these are currently localised threats, their scope and severity are expected to increase in the coming decades. Their impact on the species' should be monitored.

Livestock grazing also takes place throughout the species' distribution, but the presence of pasture prevents the conversion of grassland habitats to other land uses, such as crops and silviculture. In addition, the species appears to tolerate the presence of livestock in its grassland habitat. Therefore, the current type and intensity of livestock grazing is not considered a threat (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
population: Despite collection efforts in Parque Nacional da Serra do Cipó and surroundings areas, between 1973 and 2015, no individuals were found. Only in 2016, were individuals found at the type locality again. Its particular breeding habits mean that it might have escaped detection in surveys within its range. Due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' grassland and savannah habitat, the overall population trend is inferred to be decreasing.

habitat: This species is endemic to the Cerrado biome. The type locality is a ravine below a plateau, which contains both gallery forest and the open shrub habitat of the Cerrado savanna biome. The species was found in the vegetation along streams flowing through the bottom of the ravine, in the gallery forests and shrubland. Breeding takes place by larval development in the streams. It does not adapt well to anthropogenic disturbance (Haddad et al. 2016).
threats: Exploitation of the Cerrado habitats in this region has converted the majority of the habitat on the plateaus. Satellite imagery seems to indicate that crop cultivation is extending to the very edges of these plateaus, if it did not already reach that far. It is unknown whether the species previously occurred in the natural habitats on the plateaus prior to conversion, as the agricultural activities predate our knowledge of this species' presence. Presently, the species' shrub and forest habitat in the ravines of the type locality is being cleared to create pasture for livestock, which constitutes an ongoing major threat. In addition, the ravines occur directly below a plateau entirely covered in intensive, commercial corn and soybean monocultures. Because surface and groundwater flow down into these ravines, pesticide and fertilizer runoff is thought to be a major threat to this stream-breeding species.
population: Due to the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.

habitat: The type series originated from a region within the Cerrado biome. Some congeners are forest obligates, while others are savanna species, but the general habitat and microhabitat of this species within the biome are unknown (Brazil Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Regarding its breeding strategy, congeners are typically explosive breeders with larval development associated with temporary ponds. If the species occurs in savannah, it might be tolerant of its habitat being used for livestock pasture, but if it is a forest species, it is unlikely to tolerate the opening up of its habitat.
threats: The species' habitat preferences and tolerance to disturbance are unknown, hence the specific threats are unknown. Generally, in this part of Goiás, there is little forest remaining except for small fragments and the remaining riparian forest along the Rio Araguaia, because it has been converted to agricultural uses. In addition, much of the savannah is being used for livestock grazing and is burned seasonally to maintain the pastures. However, if the species can survive in pastureland, the degradation of the natural savannah may not be a threat, but the frequency and intensity of seasonal burns could still present a threat.
population: This species is still known only from the type series, which is comprised of two individuals collected in 1950. The lack of records since that time is probably due to a combination of factors: either a lack of surveys at the right time of year, or because the species is difficult to detect, or because it is being recorded but confused with a congener, or even because this species is a synonym of Chiasmocleis albopunctatus (Brazil Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). As a result, there is no information on the population status of this species.

habitat: It is known from the Cerrado (sensu stricto), open and forested areas, and cultivated, anthropogenically influenced areas with a particular association to Brachiara grasses. It is particularly associated with the sub-basins that drain the Araguaia River, State of Goiás, and can be found in various terrestrial microhabitats including on bare soil, within vegetation and also under rocks. Within the Cerrado dry season, this species has been observed in an active state on the ground within riparian and gallery forest habitats (Vaz-Silva and Maciel 2011). Based on information from congeners it is assumed to breed via deposition of eggs upon leaf litter, with males performing parental care and transporting them on their backs to local water bodies as the tadpoles develop.
threats: The Cerrado biome is being subjected to increasing deforestation, charcoal production, and the construction of hydroelectric dams.
